column14: C/o Convulsions × 3 years  He has had seizures for 3 years unprovoked; seizures are generalised tonic clonic seizures. Parents initially thought they were demonic attacks. column14: Presenting Complaint: 1. Poor Sleep 6/12  2. Head banging > 3 years    4 years and 1/2 Female referred by neurosurgeon with major complaints of self-injurious behaviour including head banging and pinching herself for over 3 years. Also reports poor sleep for about six months. Mother reports giving child Piriton to help with sleep.   Noted that child doesn't play with other children. Doesn't usually respond to name when called. Child doesn't point to what she wants. She always cries and mother has to figure out what the child needs. Child is also on management for epilepsy since 6 months of age but seizures are not well controlled despite adherence to regimen.   Noted that child has visual impairment was reportedly reviewed by an ophthalmologist who reported no noticeable deficits. No clear h/o hearing impairment. Mother also reports that child cannot chew.   There is a delay in all developmental milestones. Child only just recently started walking following physiotherapy. Child lacks speech and can only say about 3 words.  Mother reports normal pregnancy and delivery and reports that child was okay until immunization at about 6 months when she shortly developed seizures. Has 2 elder siblings who are in good health.    O/E 4-year-old. Good Nutritional status. Sitting on mother's lap. Didn't respond to name when called. When child stood up, she kept moving in circles.  Noted child has no speech. When she gets hungry, she cries and is inconsolable. Also noted that when month attempted to feed her, she couldn't chew. column14: 8-year-old Female school aged child diagnosed with Absence (Childhood Absence Epilepsy) currently on Sodium Valproate 300 mg BD for about 6/12 now, presenting with a history of   1) episodes of seizure starting since 3 years of life  Mother reports history of episodes of staring and abnormal behaviour where she does not respond after being called and just stares for about 10 minutes when she was 3 years. No history of aggressiveness, no hyperactivity or speaking uncontrollably, no associated history of jerking of the body during an episode of staring. This is also not provoked by noise or light and is quite unpredictable. Symptoms worsening after initiation of phenobarbital. There is no history of auditory or visual hallucinations but reports episodes of speaking uncoordinated words.  Prior to the onset of these symptoms, reportedly had several episodes of malaria with associated overt convulsions at about 1 and 2 years of age with the recent one being at Two and a half years of age.  Noted family history of these symptoms - uncle (maternal) has epilepsy.  No prior history of measles/ body rash reported in the early childhood period.  NB: Symptoms significantly reduced after initiation of Sodium Valproate.    ROS: Unremarkable- No history of HIE/ Jaundice/ Early neonatal seizures    Nutrition/ Immunisation/Development: Unremarkable - Performs well in class. No developmental challenges or delays reported    Family Social History: 2nd born of 3 children; stays with both parents. Maternal uncle has epilepsy. Child is in P2 and performs well in class.    O/E: Good general condition, no pallor, no jaundice, no dehydration and afebrile.    CNS: Alert: Coherent speech, oriented in person, place and time. Normal muscle bulk, power, tone, normal reflexes and normal sensation.    P/A: Soft, no organomegalies    CVS: Warm peripheries, Heart Sounds I + II heard, no added sounds  Chest: Vesicular breath sounds    Noted EEG: Suggestive of childhood absence epilepsy    Imp: 8-year-old female with Childhood Absence Epilepsy (fairly controlled on sodium valproate)    Plan 1) Tabs Sodium Valproate 300 mg bd × 3/12  2)  Tabs Folic Acid 5 mg od × 3/12

column14: A referral from Uganda Friendship Hospital- Naguru (Paediatric OPD) by Dr. Kamugisha for a second opinion regarding treatment in a child with refractory seizures.    This 8-year-old child has been well until the age of five, when he went for a visit to his father's home and got an unknown febrile illness. This was associated with frequent convulsions and swelling of the body. He used to have visual hallucinations and see scary things before the convulsions. The convulsions are generalised tonic clonic, last approximately 5 minutes followed by deep sleep and later a painful throat and confusion. He has since been on treatment from the age of 6 years, with minimal improvement. Currently he is on Sodium Valproate 500 mg od, Phenobarbitone 15 mg nocte and Carbamazepine 200 mg bd.  He is a student in top class but has not been able to join primary one because of the illness. He is a paternal orphan and stays with his maternal grandmother since the age of 8/12. Mother is alive; works in a bakery (Super loaf) in Kawempe.  No family h/o familial illnesses  Prenatal and natal history reported as normal (not verified)  Growth and Development has been on track up until this illness began.  Occasionally has unusual behaviour, gets episodes of amnesia and unusual eating habits, as well as incontinence of urine and faeces.    O/E: Afebrile, has multiple scalp + facial scars, no anaemia, no jaundice, no edema, no oral sores, has missing teeth (lower incisors), no skin rash.    Systems Exam: Unremarkable    EEG done October 2020: Features of 1? generalised epilepsy    EEG done 28th February 2023: Normal sleep record    Imp: Poorly controlled Generalized Epilepsy    Plan: Step up Sodium Valproate 375 mg bd  2. Keep on CBZ 200 mg bd  3. Taper down Phenobarbitone then stop

Continue Levetiracetam 250 mg bd    01/08/2024  Weight - 24.3 kg    Reviewed this 7-year-old second child who has a complex epilepsy disorder- has absences myoclonic jerks, focal seizures and GTC seizures. However, the seizure starts in one arm and moves to involve the rest of the body. Father not certain on which side of the body it starts. Has had 5 seizures in the month of July seizures mainly early in the morning.    O/E: Afebrile, no anaemia, no jaundice, no edema and no oral sores, well hydrated.    Systems: Unremarkable      Imp: Possible Doose Syndrome  In view of CBZ sometimes making seizures worse in Doose Syndrome. Let's slowly taper CBZ and stop. Let's introduce Levetiracetam. Continue Sodium Valproate. Revie in 1/12 month.

column14: 9-year-old/Female school going child, presented with history of   1. Recurrent seizures × 1 year  Mother reports that she was generally well until 1 year prior to this clinic review when she developed history of generalised tonic clonic seizures, sudden onset; involves jerking of the upper and lower limbs with upward eye deviation, mostly occurring during sleep and lasting about 3 minutes and occasionally up to 30 minutes with associated loss of consciousness and no associated fevers. Reportedly had at least 4-5 episodes. No history of visual hallucinations or auditory hallucinations before the seizure onset.  Significantly she reports that before the onset of these symptoms, the child was hospitalized ~ 4 months before the initial onset of seizures in a peripheral clinic where she presented with convulsions and was managed for 1 day? for severe malaria. No history of prior trauma.    Review of other systems:   GIT: No vomiting, no abdominal pain/ recurrent abdominal pain, no abdominal distension.    PMH/PSH: No history of any known chronic illnesses, no history of recent admission, not on any chronic medications, no history of trauma or blood transfusion.    ANC/Perinatal history: Attended ANC 6 times. Born by SVD, Birth Weight 3.2 kg, no history of any significant perinatal events.    Growth and Development history: Achieved milestones appropriately sat at 5/12, started walking at 11 months, social smile at 3 months and started speaking monosyllables at ~ 1 year.    Nutrition history: Exclusively breastfed for 6/12, weaned off on mashed Irish potatoes, cow's milk (occasionally); meat soup and now feeding on the rest of family foods.    Immunisation history: Up to date > completed all scheduled immunisations (no evidence of immunisation card, no BCG Scar)    Family Social History: She is 3rd born of 4 children; currently in Primary 3 - Performing well. No family history of epilepsy or any seizure disorder. Rest of children are well. Stays with both parents who are supportive - mother is a shop keeper. Father is a chef, works in Somalia for now.    O/E Good general condition, appears well, no pallor, no jaundice, no dehydration, well-nourished weight 27.3 kg, no significant lymphadenopathy, no finger clubbing, no peripheral stigmata of CVS disease, noted mild left pina (auricular) - excoriation, no obvious purulent discharge.    P/A: Soft, no organomegalies, non-tender.    CNS: Fully conscious, GCS 15/15, neck soft, pupils equal + reactive, well oriented in time, space, person, normal tone, normal power, normal reflexes, normal coordination, normal gait. Normal sensation, no obvious craniopathies.    CVS: warm peripheries, capillary refill < 2 seconds, HS I + I + II + 0 No added sounds.    Chest: RR = 19 cycles/min, vesicular breath sounds, equal air entry.    Imp: 9-year-old/ Female 1. Epilepsy (? Benign childhood epilepsy ?Post malarial sequelae    Plan: let's do EEG    Noted results of the EEG - Abnormal waking EEG due to (25/01/2023) Occasional Isolated spikes or spike and wave complexes in right central region. The findings are suggestive of focal epilepsy.    Imp:? Focal Epilepsy    Consulted Prof Idro; and he said this is most likely - familial nocturnal epilepsy syndrome and recommended that we initiate on    1. Tabs Sodium Valproate 200 mg bd × 3/12

One week ago, baby was again admitted at Acute Care Unit due to excessive crying, convulsions and inability to feed; spent one day admitted and was given review to neuroclinic. Currently mother reports sudden brief abnormal movements that the baby does using both upper and lower limbs but with no loss of consciousness.    PMH (Past Medical History): Has been admitted 3 times (index admission at Kibuli Hospital, second at Women's Hospital, Third at ACU (Acute Care Unit) Mulago. Mother is HIV seropositive for 4 years on HAART from MARPI, baby had DNA PCR at 6 weeks which was negative.    PSH (Past Surgical History): No hx (history) of any surgeries/ blood transfusions.    Birth history: Mother attended ANC from Kibuli Hospital delivered child by SVD however reports prolonged labour. Birth Weight 3.5 kg. Post natal period: Baby had high grade fevers (reportedly) but mother was told to expose the baby and discharged home.    Immunisation Hx (History): UpToDate    Family Social History: 4th born of 4. Other children are well. Mother and father stay together. Mother and Father are businesspeople. Baby sleeps under a mosquito net. No familial history of epilepsy/other diseases such as SCD (Sickle Cell Disease)    Nutritional History: Exclusive breast feeding.    Growth and Development: Not able to sit but able to smile.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition). afebrile, no anaemia, no jaundice, no dehydration and no edema.    CNS: Poor head control, microcephaly, Anterior Fontanel - Normotensive     Resp: Not in respiratory distress, equal air entry bilaterally. Chest clear.    CVS: Warm peripheries. HS I +II heard and normal.    P/A: Normal fullness. Soft, no palpable organs    Imp: A 4-month-old/F with poor development - post meningitis sequelae ? Cerebral Palsy, ?Epilepsy, ?Infantile Spasms    Plan: 1. Do Brain EEG (Review with results)     23/03/2023  Weight: 6.6 kg  4/12-month-old/F with a history of convulsions, has a h/o (history of) being managed for neonatal meningitis    EEG done shows features suggestive of focal epilepsy    Has not had any convulsions since the last admission.  No new concerns  Was started on Levetiracetam 3/7 days ago at IHK (International Hospital Kampala)    O/E: In FGC (Fair General Condition), Afebrile, no anaemia, no jaundice and no dehydration    Systemic R/V (Review) - Unremarkable    Imp: 4/12 with Focal Epilepsy    Plan: 1. Continue Levetiracetam 0.5 mls once daily × 1/12  2. To come in with medication and prescription.

column11: Severe Epileptic Encephalopathy (Landau Kleffner Syndrome) 2? to Myoclonic Astatic epilepsy.
column14: 10/01/2022  Severe Epileptic Encephalopathy (Landau Kleffner Syndrome) 2? to Myoclonic Astatic epilepsy.  H/o Previous Neonatal Jaundice and Developmental Delay/ Recent Regression.    1.Tabs Prednisolone 20 mg bd × 1/52  2. Tabs Clobazam 5 mg (am) 5 mg (pm) 10 mg (nocte) × 1/52  3. Syrup Sodium Valproate 200 mg (am) 300 mg (nocte) × 1/52  4. Review in 1/52 with EEG Repeat  5. Tabs Esomeprazole 10 mg od × 1/52    24/01/2023  4-year 8/12-month-old/ Male,   Atten; Dr.S.Kamya  Prof.M.Kawooya,  Kindly review and give a second opinion on these images.  Malik is a 4-year 8/12-month-old boy with intractable epilepsy with myoclonic astatic epilepsy, epileptic encephalopathy and Landau Kleffner Syndrome. Seizures are currently controlled on  - Clobazam 5 mg (am), 5 mg (pm) and 10 mg (nocte)  - Sodium Valproate 200 mg (am), 300 mg (nocte)  - Prednisolone 20 mg bd  He had h/o - Neonatal Jaundice  - Speech delay and abnormal behaviour  and now developmental regression    A recent brain MRI - inconclusively- a possibility of periventricular nodular Heteropia. Please review the images and provided a second opinion. I will also write to either of UCLA or frank at Emory to have a second look. Please make the image available on PACS or icloud for them to access.    Prescription for today  1. Tabs Clobazam 5 mg (am), 10 mg (nocte) × 1/52  2. Syrup Sodium Valproate 200 mg (am), 300 mg (nocte) × 1/52  3. Tabs Prednisolone 15 mg bd × 3/7,  10 mg bd × 3/7, 5 mg bd × 2/7  4. Sachets esomeprazole 10 mg od × 1/52  Review after 1/52

Mother reports that the boy has been having recurrent a febrile generalised tonic clonic convulsions associated with loss of consciousness, each episode lasting ~ 3 minutes, self-terminating. Averagely 4 episodes per week. No history of SCA (Sickle Cell Anaemia) associated stroke.    ROS (Review of other systems)  GIT: Recurrent abdominal pain associated with yellow discolouration of the eyes. No vomiting or diarrhea.  CVS: No complaints  R/S: No complaints  MSK (Musculoskeletal system) - Joint and bone pains    PMHx (Past Medical History): Apart from SCA (Sickle Cell Anaemia), he reports no other chronic illnesses such as CKD or stroke.    PSHx: He's been transfused twice, most recent BT (July 2022). No hx of trauma.    Growth and Development: He's been growing normally but with poor academic performance due to convulsions.    Family Social History: 1st born. 3 siblings alive and well - both parents alive (mother - house wife) Dad - company driver    O/E An adolescent, FGC (Fair General Condition), bilateral scalp bossing, tinge of jaundice, moderate pallor, no digital clubbing.    CNS: Fully consciousness, GCS (E-4, V-5, M-6) 15/15, No meningeal irritation, no craniopathy.    R/S (Respiratory System): Unremarkable    CVS: Unremarkable    Imp: 13/M SCA (Sickle Cell Epilepsy), Epilepsy    Noted - Normal EEG    Plan: Do Transcranial doppler USS (To screen the risk of stroke) and Brain MRI  Meanwhile  1. Tabs Sodium Valproate 200 mg (am) 400 mg (pm) × 1/12  2. Continue SCA (Sickle Cell Anaemia) Care

column14: Presenting complaint: Left sided focal convulsions since 7 months of age    HPC (History of Presenting Complaint): Nicole 2 years 10/12-month-old female was relatively growing well until 7/12 months of age when she developed focal convulsions involving the whole left side (limbs and face), would last more than 5 minutes, associated with loss of consciousness, drooling of saliva, upward gaze. Not associated with fever, faecal or urine incontinence. The last episode was earlier this month. Child has not been taking any medication (only herbal medication) She is currently staying with her grandmother, who has been with her for about one year. Grandmother also reports right sided facial lesion that is red in colour since birth.     ROS (Review of other systems): Unremarkable    PMHx (Past Medical History): Child has never been admitted. She was managed for TB at 8 months of age and completed treatment. No known food or drug allergies. Not on chronic medication. Maternal serostatus unknown.     Past Surgical History: No history of surgeries    Birth History: Mother attended ANC (Antenatal Care) at Kisenyi HC IV (Details not known by the grandmother) Delivered preterm by SVD (Spontaneous Vaginal Delivery), birth weight 2. 0 kg, cried immediately and reports no complications postnatally.    Nutritional history: Child breastfed up to 1 year of age. Exclusively breastfed up to 4 months? (Grandmother not sure)    Growth and Development: Child was growing well until 7 months, started sitting at about 6 months and started crawling. However, at 7/12 months when this seizure began. Child regressed. Had delayed milestones, walked at about 2 years of life. Currently able to call mama. Able to ask for something.    Immunisation History: Fully immunised - according to the card.    Family Social History: Only child, currently stays with the grandmother, mother gave birth at ~ 17 years of age. Parent's don't stay together. Mother is a casual labourer and father's occupation is unknown (works in a market). No known family history of epilepsy.    O/E: Toddler, In FGC, afebrile, hair is black and well distributed, not wasted, scalp lesions, no oral thrush, no lymphadenopathy, has a hyperemic shin lesion on the rights side of the face? Pot wine stain?  Weight: 11.6 kg, MUAC (Mid Upper Arm Circumference): 84.7 cm    CNS: Active, alert, no signs of meningism, no abnormal movement, limbs are symmetrical, no obvious wasting, no fasciculation or involuntary movements. Normal muscle bulk, normal tone and power, normal reflexes. Has strabismus of the right eye, no other craniopathies. PEARL (Pupils Equal and Reactive to Light)    CVS: Warm extremities, CRT < 3 seconds, HS I+II +0 Heard.    R/S: Not in respiratory distress, Broncho vesicular breath sounds with equal air entry  P/A (Per Abdomen): Normal fullness, soft, no palpable masses.    Noted EEG done: Normal Findings    Imp: 2 years 10/12-month-old female with  1. Possible Sturge Weber Syndrome  2. Tinea Capitis    Plan: 1. Sodium Valproate 150 mg od × 2/52  2. Tabs griseofulvin 125 mg od × 6/52  3. Review  4. To do brain CT Scan

column14: C/o Convulsion    Seen 5/M with history of convulsion since 1 year and a half. The last episode reported to be last week. Mother reports that she noticed the 1st episode at 1 and half years of age, it was of sudden onset and the convulsions involved the right upper and lower limbs, rolling of eyes, faecal and urine incontinence during the convulsion. This would take more than an hour then later loss consciousness, for like 15 - 30 minutes, not aware of what was going on after. This has not been associated with fever. Mother reports similar episodes several times since that age of 1 year and a half up to 3 years. All that time she has been attending some peripheral hospitals, but no medication was given to control the seizures. column14: Presenting Complaints: Convulsions at night × 4 years    HPC (History Presenting Complaining): Reviewed of 5/M, who was well until 4 years ago when he started having abnormal movements at night. He started having progressive 5 episodes in last year.  Father reports that all this started 4 years ago with 1episode in year, then the following year it progressed to monthly episodes and recently they have increased to 5 episodes in the last 3 months.  The abnormal movements come in form of convulsions at night which are generalised tonic clonic happening for 15-20 minutes and associated with urine and faecal incontinence. Also reports no known precipitating factors. No history of fevers. Also associated with post-ictal phase of loss of consciousness for about 15 minutes. However during day, there is no episode reported.    ROS (Review Other of System)  R/S: No history of cough and flue. No h/o (history of) difficulty in breathing  P/A: No history of vomiting, passing loose stool. No abdominal distension.  MSK (Musculoskeletal system): No history of any deformities of lower.  PMHx (Past Medical History): This is the index admission. Has had several episodes of convulsions in the last 4 years and has not been on any treatment. No h/o any chronic illness.    PSHx (Past Surgical History): No h/o (history of) surgeries done, No h/o (history of) blood transfusion.    Antenatal hx (history): (Mother did not escort child). Father reports the mother of the child attended ANC (Antenatal Care) and followed the schedule.    Natal hx: Mother was no difficulty during delivery (SVD). He cried immediately and was discharged home.    Immunisation hx (history): Father not sure    Nutritional hx (history): He was breastfed exclusively up to 6 months then started mixed feeding. Feeding well with a diet good in quality and quantity.    Family Social History: He is the 4th born, currently staying with father and grandmother. (mother went abroad)  No history of epilepsy or mental illness in the family.    Developmental hx (history): Attained all the required milestones UpToDate.     Summary: Review 5/M presented with a 4-year history of generalised tonic clonic convulsions which have increasing gradually in frequency and occur at night only (while asleep) associated with urine and faecal incontinence and lasting 15-20 minutes with a post-ictal period of about 20 mins.    O/E: In FGC (Fair General Condition), No jaundice, no pallor, no cyanosis, no dehydration, no oedema and afebrile.    CNS: Conscious and fully alert, GCS 15/15. No signs of meningeal irritation. Kerning -ve.     P/A: Normal fullness, soft, non-tender, no palpable organs.    R/S (Respiratory System): Not in obvious respiratory distress. Equal air entry bilaterally.    Imp: 5/M with Benign childhood epilepsy (features on EEG - Focal epileptiform discharges from a normal background)    Plan: 1. Start treatment (Sodium Valproate)  2. Monitor while on treatment.  3. Counselling  4. Come back after 1 month  5. Sodium Valproate 15 mg/kg (2 divided dose) 234 mg, 117 mg bd × 1/12

column15: Seen 8/M who was apparently will until 5th of April this year when he developed the 1st episode of convulsions. Father reports that the child started with jerks of the right hand which took ten minutes, and the child was awake. Has reported 20 episodes of seizures since it started on different days, the seizures have been progressive in a way that the right leg also was involved with jerks and stiffness also increased movement of the abdominal muscles, the longest episode has taken like 1 hour however no loss of consciousness, no urine or faecal incontinence, no fever. He was taken to the hospital due to seizures at different occasions. At first it was at a clinic where he was managed for malaria, the 2nd time he was brought to Mulago; this was like 2 weeks ago when he was given phenobarbitone but there was no improvement. The child has been growing well. No history of admission. The child has been in school doing well, currently in P3 (Primary 3) and he is among top five.

column14: Presenting Complaint: Convulsions × 1 year and a half    HPC (History of Presenting Complaint): 8-year-old/ Female who has been unwell since infanthood, with history of delayed growth and development associated with abnormal behaviour. No history of fever or projectile vomiting. No identifiable trigger or relieving factor for the convulsion.    ROS (Review of Other Systems):  R/S, CVS, GIT: No complaints  MSK (Musculoskeletal system): Inability to walk due to lower limb deformities.    PMHx (Past Medical History): History of global developmental delay. No known hx of stroke or epilepsy. No known drug or food allergies.    PSHx (Past Surgical History): Underwent 2- neuro surgical operations due of a brain mass that she was born with at 2 weeks and 2 months.    ANC: Multiple gestation, screen for HIV and syphilis - All negative    Birth history: 1st twin, born at term, birth weight 1 kg, cried immediately and breastfed normally but had a head mass and limb deformities. No history of birth asphyxia or neonatal jaundice.    Post natal hx (history): She was operated for brain mass at 2 weeks of age and 2 months.    Immunisation: UpToDate as per Ugandan schedule.    Nutritional hx (history): Adequate in both proteins and carbohydrates, no feeding difficulties.    Growth and Development: Has not been growing normally, started sitting at 1 year, has never walked or stool and no speech.    Family Social History: 1st twin both parents alive, mom-house wife, father-builder. 2nd twin in P2, doing well. No family history of epilepsy.    Problems  1. Convulsions  2. Inability to walk and talk    Strengths  1. Feeds well  2. She's a happy girl - interacts well with mom and siblings.    O/E: School age, well nourishes, not sick looking, no pallor or jaundice. microcephaly with occipital surgical scar, she looks happy & smiling.    CNS: Fully conscious, HC (Head Circumference) = 43/ small, neck soft, normal tone in upper limbs, hypertonia in lower limbs. Occipital surgical scar    R/S: Not in distress, equal air entry bilaterally broncho vesicular breath sounds and no added sounds.    CVS: CRT < 2 sec normal volume regular pulse, Heart Sounds I + II normal.    P/A: Normal fullness, feeding normally and no organomegaly.    MSK (Musculoskeletal System): Normal muscle bulk in upper limbs skeletal deformities in lower limbs.    Problems  1. Unprovoked convulsions  2. Limited movement, no speech    Strengths  1. Ability to feed normally    Imp: 8-year-old/Female 1st twin  Epilepsy    Plan: 1. Do EEG  2. To get documents for the previous surgery  3. Tabs Sodium Valproate 250 mg od × 1/12 (@15mg/kg/day)

column14: Weight: 11.6 kg  c/o Drop attacks ~ 6/12 months    HPC (History of Presenting Complaint): Has been unwell ~ 6/12 with episodes described as suddenly drops on the ground associated with post ictal states of excessive sleep ~ 2 hours before fully walking up  Noted that the last episode occurred ~ 5/7 days ago where he had ~ 2-3 episodes but the last episode involved GTCs (Generalised Tonic Convulsions) with stool and urine incontinence and frothing.  Noted episodes are worse during the presence of respiratory tract infections.  Episodes occur when he has spiking fevers.    NB: The drop attacks are associated initially with visual hallucination and excessive.     Birth history: The child was delivered by C/S after ~ 12 hours of labour (but mother had 3 previous scars), doesn't remember if he cried immediately. But on day 3 of life the baby developed seizure and refusal to feed and was admitted and treated for neonatal sepsis (also Lumbar Puncture was done), was discharged after 10 days; had been oxygen therapy for 3 days. At discharge was breastfeeding.    Developmental History: Mother noted that he had developmental delay of milestones, sitting with support at 6 months, sitting without support at 8 months, crawling at 10 months, standing at 1 year and walking at 1 year 6/12 months old. Speech development is slow as he is only able to say mama, tata and bubbles other words. Plays with other children, hears but does not follow instructions.  Feeds himself now.  Immunised: Immunisation is UpToDate    FSH (Family Social History): 4th born of the family; older siblings are well, maternal history of epilepsy? (her sister used to convulse from 3 years till 12 years of age, but it didn't affect her growth)    O/E: Well-nourished child, afebrile 36.0? C, not pale and no jaundice.    CNS: GCS 15/15, PEARL (Pupils Equal and Reactive to Light), soft neck, walks arounds and climbs chairs, normal tone, reflexes, power and sensation.  Noted suckling of the lips.    Chest: RR-22 bpm, Equal air entry and normal breath sounds.    CNS: Heart Sounds I + II heard and normal, PR - 118 bpm    P/A (Per Abdomen): Normal fullness, soft, non-tender and no masses    Imp: Occipital lobe Epilepsy  R/O Hypoglycemic Occipital Epilepsy    Plan:  1. Do EEG  2. Do MRI  3. Stat Epilim 15mg/kg/day

column14: Weight: 32.0 kg  Age: 13 years    Presenting Complaint: Seizures × 9 years  History of Presenting Complaint: Has been with seizures since age 2 years. Previously on carbamazepine AT 1 TAB b.d but with poor control. Child had a dose escalated 4 days ago to 21mg/kg/day and has not had any seizures. Has been living with her maternal aunty, recently brought to the father and step mother who doesn't know a lot of her history.  She has observed seizures characterised by abnormal movement of the Right Upper Limb (tonic) with eye rolling and frothing followed by drowsiness. Each episode lasts ~ 20 minutes.    ROS: Unremarkable  Family Social History: 1st born to the mother. Father is polygamous and has several children currently living with the stepmother who has two younger children. Father is supportive.    O/E: Young is in good general condition, afebrile. Noted a large burn wound on the right infra-axillary region ~ 30 × 20 cm with crusting.    Other systems: Normal findings    Imp: Fairly controlled seizure disorder    Plan: Continue P.O Carbamazepine 300 mg (am) 400 mg (Nocte) × 2/12

column14: Presenting Complaint: Seizures × 1 year and a half    History of Presenting Complaint: Baby had seizures since age 10 months. Gets generalised tonic seizures each lasting ~ 2-3 minutes followed by drowsiness and regression in milestones. Can fail to walk for the next 4 days or more following the seizure  Seizures are not provoked by fever. Child has had delayed speech and can only call daddy.  Sat at 6 months, walked at 10/12 months.  Has also had a small head since birth was given CBZ 2weeks ago and has been seizure free.    ROS (Review of Other Systems): Unremarkable.    PMHx (Past Medical History): Known patient of Sickle Cell Disease. Diagnosed at 1 year.    Antenatal Care/ Perinatal Care: Mother attended ANC (Antenatal Care) 5 times. Started at 3/12 months. Pregnancy was unremarkable. Did not test for syphilis, HIV was negative. Delivered term at a HC III, Birth Weight 3.9 kg. Cried immediately but had a small head. Uneventful neonatal period.    Family Social History: 1st born to both parents who live together. Father is a driver; mother is a hairdresser.     O/E: Good General Condition, playful toddler with flu.    CNS: Fully conscious, Pupils Equal and Reactive to Light, head looks small for the body. Occipital-frontal head Circumference = 45.9 cm (below 3rd percentile for age and sex) Normal tone and reflexes. Walks with a wide based gait.    Other systems - Unremarkable    Noted EEG - Features of mild cerebral dysfunction. No epileptiform activity detected.    Impression: Seizure disorder  Microcephaly  SCA (Sickle Cell Anaemia)    Plan: Continue P.O Carbamazepine 50 mg (am) 100 mg (nocte) × 2/12  Speech therapy

column14: C/o (Complaints of): Seizures × 3 years    History of Presenting Complaint:   Seizure semiology: He started when he was 8 years old. It starts with twitching/ deviation of the month to one side, followed by extension of both upper limbs with increase in tone in the upper limbs. The limbs also become flexed and have increased tone. During the seizure, there is voice production (phonation) and drooling of saliva and there is impaired consciousness. No stool or urine incontinence. It lasts about an hour and may become repetitive in a day. The seizure is preceded by an aura- He gets annoyed and irritable, gets a headache and feels dizzy. After the seizure, he goes into sleep. Generally, no change in behaviour or personality. School going, in P.4 (before lockdown). No known family history of epilepsy. Stays with father and stepmother. He has four siblings.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), Afebrile, no anaemia, no jaundice and no cyanosis.    CNS: Alert, conscious and no craniopathy.    Other systems: Unremarkable.    EEG: Focal Epilepsy (Left Temporal)    Imp: Focal Epilepsy    Plan: 1. Tabs Carbamazepine 300 mg bd × 3/12  2. Patient Education done

column14: C/o Seizures × 2 years    History of Presenting Complaint: Noted 7-year-old/Male who has had seizures for 2 years.  Seizure semiology: Seizures started at 5 years of age occur during sleep, characterised by flexion pf both upper and lower limbs, with increase in stiffness, no jerks, associated up rolling of eyes, no voice production, urinary incontinence. During the seizure, awareness is impaired. The seizures are preceded by some warning signs of abnormal behaviour of laughing by himself, fearfulness and loose motions. After the seizures, which normally last 3-10 minutes, he becomes weak and drools saliva. Also has disturbed speech and poor school performance.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), no anaemia, no jaundice, no cyanosis, no dehydration.    CNS: Alert, soft neck. No craniopathy. Normal Gait.    EEG: Features are of focal epilepsy (bifrontal).    Imp: Focal Epilepsy    Plan: 1. Tabs Carbamazepine 150 mg bd × 2/52

column14: 03/02/2022  1/12-month-old child referred to the Neuroclinic from Kawempe National Referral Hospital with a diagnosis of a seizure disorder as a neurologic sequelae of HIE-grade III. She was discharged 4/7 days ago, but still has a weak cry and is not able to breastfeed well. Feeds through an Ng-tube. R/S: Not in distress, equal air entry bilaterally, bronchovesicular breathe sounds, no added sounds.    Impression: Seizure Disorder  Plan: Syrup Sodium Valproate 65 mg bd × 1/12.

column51: 2 years 11/12 month old Male first referred to us in Mrach 2022 for ADHD assessment. Assessment revealed dysregulation due to a seizure disorder; not ADHD. Mother reports that the concerns she had that time of hyperactivity and impulsiveness have reduced and is not her concern today.  Her concern is frequent falls and injuries to the head which she attributes to differnet presentation of seizures. She reports that generalised tonic clonic convulsions was last in July. Now child gets frequent sudden drops. Mother reports observing that it comes when he pays attention. He falls more forwards though at times falls backwards. He doesn't care when playing and running about. Mother has had to buy head gear (Helmet) to protect his head. Otherwise sleeps well and feeds well except when he gets attacks.    Assessment: Appears his age; has healing scars on prominent areas of his head at different stages of healing.  Behaviour: Came into the room and we observed one of the drop attacks. He remained conscious and started crying immediately. Stopped crying after being soothed. He started playing, maintains eye contact, plays with toys in a fast manner.  Speech: No words heard, but reports one word ability.  Impression: Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.  Plan: 1. Need a repeat EEG.  2. Continue Tabs Sodium Valproate 150 mg (am) 300 mg (nocte) × 2/52  3. Stop Carbamazepine  4. Tabs Clobazam 2.5 mg od × 3/7 then 2.5 mg bd × 2/52

column14: Weight: 9.0 kg    Referral from Mengo Hospital following recent admission for severe febrile disease with refractory status epilepticus × 18/7    History of Presenting Complaint: Initially had a fever, diarrhea and vomiting for 3/7 days and then developed seizures and lapsed into coma.  -Was managed for meningoencephalitis, overwhelming sepsis, urosepsis and metabolic acidosis.  -Had intractable seizures × 1/52 controlled on continuous infusion of midazolam.  -Treatment with Meropenem/ Amikacin. No growth in the cultures    Was discharged seizure free × 5/7, no fever but unable to feed, unable to sit and with impaired vision on  -Levetiracetam 150 mg bd  -Sodium Valproate 80 mg bd    Had an EEG on 18-03-2022 - Showing - abnormal slowing with (Left) Hemisphere sharp and slow waves.    Past Medical History: Normal Pregnancy - (6th). Delivered by Elective C/S - Birth Weight 2.9 kg. All the siblings are well, but all have delayed motor development. Walking at 14-16 months. No immediate perinatal problems and no major problem.    Development: Delayed significantly sat at 9/12 months. At 15/12 months was cruising around tables, unable to walk, but could call mama.   Since then, regressed.    O/E: Good general condition. Non-dysmorphic, anterior fontanelle - normal and normal head circumference, no anaemia and no jaundice.    CNS - Alert but abnormal visual behaviour - poor focus, mild (right) external squint. Poor neck control.  -Abnormal movements of especially the upper limbs and fingers.  -Increased tone in all limbs - especially upper limbs and mildly increased reflexes.    The rest of the systemic exam is normal.    Impression: 1. Previous unexplained developmental delay.  2. Recent meningoencephalitis with severe sequelae - now recovering    Plan: 1. Brain MRI/Diagnostic  2. CK, Vitamin D  3. Vitamin D 1000 IU od × 1/12  4. Levetiracetam 150 mg bd × 1/12  5. Sodium Valproate 80 mg bd × 1/12

Growth and Development: She is not yet able to support her neck while seated with support.    Immunisation history: Immunisation is UpToDate. column14: 9-year-old/ Male patient with ? Cerebral Palsy who came in with a diagnosis of Focal Epilepsy on Carbamazepine 100 mg nocte and 200 mg evening.    Presenting Complaint: 1. Convulsions (unilateral) × 2/7  2. Failure to walk × 2/52  3. Constipation × 1/52    Patients has been unwell since birth.  Was born as a twin at 7 months (preterm) and came in with convulsions about 2 episodes in a week lasting about 5 hours one sided, involving the right side (both arm and leg) associated with up rolling of eyes and movement of the mouth and loss of consciousness. was not yet on anticonvulsants. No history of fever also gets excessive salivation and urine incontinence. Post-ictal loss of consciousness. Able to see and hear. Unable to walk for about 2/52 weeks. Previously walked on heels but is now unable to walk. Also has constipation. No vomiting, able to feed on his own and has lost weight.     R/S (Respiratory System): No cough, no flu and no difficulty in breathing.    CNS: Has easy-fatiguability.    GUT (Genitourinary System) Passing out urine well. Wears pampers. No pain on passing urine.    Immunisation: Child is fully immunised     Notably, mother attended ANC (Antenatal Care) thrice and was given Rx unknown to her. Reported infections during pregnancy however treatment and diagnosis is unknown to her.  Delivered at 7 months, at home, birth weight ~ 1.0 kg. Cried immediately. 1st twin died after 1 week. Was able to breastfeed and had no convulsions.    Development: Child later taken to hospital in 1 week due to excessive crying. Was able to sit at 7 months, able to stand at 9 months, walked at 1-year 5/12 months walking normally. Started to fail to walk at 4 years. Initially was normal. Had an illness of hydrocephalus in Mbale. Was later put on herbal medication, since then developed progressive difficulty in walking and talking.    Family Social History: Child is the 1st born out of 4 children. The children are okay, no history of seizure in the family. Mother stays with husband and the children. Father and mother are businesspeople.    O/E: Fair General Condition, afebrile, no jaundice, no anaemia, no dehydration and no edema.    CNS: Alert, neck soft, pupils equal and reactive to light. Neck soft. Increased tone in the upper and lower limbs. Hyperreflexia in all limbs. Power 5/5 in all limbs muscle bulk in all limbs, no craniopathy.    CVS: Heart sounds I + II heard and normal. Pulse is regular. Full volume warm extremities.     R/S: Not in distress, chest clear and equal air entry.    P/A: Has soiled pamper, urine continence. Normal fullness, non-tender, no organomegaly.    Imp: 1. Seizure disorder ?Encephalopathy  2. Hydrocephalus  3. Constipation    Plan: 1. Do Brain CT Scan, RFT's and Electrolytes  2. Tabs Carbamazepine 250 mg bd × 1/12  3. Tabs Baclofen 5 mg od × 1/12  4.  Syrup Lactulose 7.5 ml  8 hourly 5/7    EEG: Epileptic Encephalopathy left frontal and both temporal (Lt>Rt) regions.    Dx:    Rx: 1. Tab Baclofen 10 mg bd × 1/12  2. Tab carbamazepine 250 mg bd × 1/12  3. Hydration and fruit.

column14: 5/M referred from ward to attend the neuro-clinic. He has generally been unwell for > 1 year now with history of a first a febrile seizure 1 year ago at night that was generalised tonic clonic with loss of consciousness/ weakness after the seizure; This was followed by periodic/ episodic seizures all at night generalised tonic clonic  (GTC) about once/month.  -1 month ago, he was admitted for febrile seizures and then treated for malaria and 2 weeks later was admitted with febrile seizures and treated for seizures. The seizures have now been more frequent, day and night and the boy has aggressive behaviour.  -The child was delivered by SVD at term, cried immediately after birth.  -Immunisation was completed.  -The child has generally been growing well, walked at 1 year; However, has not stopped talking today.  -4th born of 4 children, 1st born is 16-year-old and on treatment for epilepsy and has impaired speech.    O/E: School-going age, no pallor and no jaundice.    R/S: Not in distress and equal air entry.    CNS: Hyper-alert, irritable, aggressive, crying and no focal neurological deficits.    Noted EEG: No epileptiform activity detected.    Impression: Epileptic Encephalopathy with generalised epilepsy.    Rx: 1. Sodium Valproate 100 mg (10mg/kg) bd × 1/12

column14: -Right sided epileptic seizures × 4 years  -Right sided hemiplegia    History of presenting complaint: 3rd child of parents of 4. Reported to have had a prolonged labour and difficult delivery. Did not cry at birth and needed stimulation and resuscitation? Birth Weight > 4.0 kg. No history of neonatal seizures or jaundice.  Delayed to sit, crawl and walk. He started to crawl at ~ 1 year and 9/12 months old after 3/12 months of physiotherapy. Walked shortly after with right-sided hemiplegia.  Currently in pre-school. 1st seizure - ~ 3 years. Right focal motor, would shout and then jerk. The right face, upper limb and lower limb. These were short, initially ~ every 3-4 months.  -But frequency and duration increased, now > weekly  -Multiple focal motor + GTC (Generalised tonic Clonic convulsions) even in school    O/E: Good general condition, has right sided facial injury, no anaemia, no jaundice, mild plagiocephaly.    CNS: Alert, fully aware, obeys commands normally.    Has right sided facial weakness with right sided hemiplegia with RUL - 2-3/5, RLL 3-4/5 and no contractures. Hemiplegic gait, normal speech with scoliosis and shortening of both RUL and RLL.    CVS: Normal    EEG: Features of focal epilepsy    Impression: Perinatal stroke and right-sided focal motor epilepsy.    Plan: 1. Tabs Carbamazepine 200 mg bd × 3/12  2. Brain CT Scan  3. Physiotherapy  4. Counselling  Started speaking simple words ~ 2 years.

column14: Weight: 10 kg    4-year-old Male toddler presented with the history of regression in all milestones.     Past Medical History: According to the caretaker; at 3 years old plus the child fails down from attendance hands and they claim that by then the child started regression of milestones (he was able to sit, crawl, pick up objects and walk with a walker), but he has never talked before these events. The child was reviewed at coRSU Rehabilitation Hospital in Entebbe, where an EEG was done and showed Focal epileptic discharge with slowing on 14/04/2021. The child was started on Carbamazepine 100 mg nocte up to now, but no one has witnessed the seizures or abnormal jerks.   The caretaker only witnesses tremors on both lower limbs.  This year the child has been admitted 5 times due to pneumonia and a times malaria.  At the last admission Sodium Valproate was added???  He also had an Echo done at Uganda Heart Institute that showed small restrictive peri membranous VSD partly closed by the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve.    Antenatal Care/ Natal/ Post Natal: According to the reports, the baby was delivered via emergency C/S due to prolonged labour, the child didn't cry immediately and was kept on oxygen for a week.  The child is fully immunised.  Has poor nutritional history due to poor appetite.   Family Social History: 1st born of 2, but mother abandoned the child with the grandmother.    O/E: The child is unwell, no conjunctival pallor, but has palmar pallor, no jaundice, afebrile with some dehydration and has frontal bossing.    CVS: Heart Sounds I + II heard and normal, there is a pansystolic murmur on the tricuspid area.     R/S: Has bilateral equal air entry with transmitted sound. No added sounds.    P/A: Soft, non-tender. Spleen is not palpable. Liver is palpable 4 cm below the costal margin and tender.    Musculoskeletal system: Has rashes all over the trunk and bowing of the lower limbs.    CNS: He is alert, no sings of meningeal irritation, has hypertonia and hyperreflexia of the right arm and both lower limbs. Anterior fontanelle spans one finger.    Impression: 4 year old Male child with  1. Small VSD  2. Micronutrient deficiency  3. Spastic Cerebral Palsy mimicker?    Plan: 1. Vitamin D syrup 600 IU once/day  2. Septrine syrup 60 mg × 1/52  To be seen in Neuroclinic on 13th July 2022    14/07/2022  Age: 4 years 1/12-month-old  Weight: 10.5 kg    Pre-school child with epileptic encephalopathy.  -Was previously well. Developed a severe febrile illness with status epilepticus.  -Regressed in all milestones.  -Developed severe epilepsy  -Lost speech  -Can feed self and requires NGT feeding  -Has spastic quadriparesis    Plan: 1. Continue Carbamazepine 100 mg (am) 200 mg (nocte) × 1/52  2. Tabs Clobazam 5 mg bd × 1/52  3. Brain CT-diagnostic  4. Repeat EEG after × 1/52  5. Add Sodium Valproate 100 mg bd × 1/52

column14: 7-year-old child with Cerebral Palsy secondary to HIE II (Hypoxic Ischaemic Encephalopathy Grade II) at birth. Mother had early rupture of membranes and prolonged labour. Child had been having convulsions since 1 year of age but mother was defaulting on the medication until 2 months ago. She was also previously attending physiotherapy but stopped during the lock down period and child now has contractures. She was also managed for SAM NE (Severe Acute Malnutrition Non-Edematous) at MNU Mulago and discharged 2 weeks ago. 3rd of 4 siblings and the rest are well. Has been seizure free since she started taking Carbamazepine 2 weeks ago.    ECHO (28/06/22): Features of focal epilepsy (Right Frontal)    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition) wasted, mild anaemia, no jaundice, no dehydration. R/S: Not in distress, Equal air entry bilaterally, normal bronchovesicular breathe sounds, transmitted sounds.    CVS: Warm extremities Heart Sounds I + II heard with no added sounds.    P/A: Scaphoid, no organs palpable    Imp: Quadriplegic Cerebral Palsy with Focal Epilepsy.    Plan: Tabs Carbamazepine 100 mg (am) 200 mg (pm) × 1/12   2. column14: Weight: 30.7 kg  An 11- and 1/2-years old Female with long standing history of focal convulsions (involving the right upper and lower limbs) since 1 and 1/2 years of age. At 5 years, she developed episodes of anxiety (gets scared and runs to adult for safety) occasionally. She is generally very slow in all her activities. One month ago, had a strange occurrence at school (Aunt describes spinning around the class but did not fall). Has been on Carbamazepine for the past 2 and 1/2 months (after an abnormal EEG).     Was delivered as a twin with LBW (Low Birth Weight) ~ 1.5 kg. Had delayed milestones as compared to her twin sister. Had SAM (Severe Acute Malnutrition) at 8 months. She is currently in Primary 2.    Family Social History: Father passed on (2 weeks ago), mother is outside the country (Oman). Currently stays with the paternal aunt. No known familial history of epilepsy or any other chronic illness.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), Afebrile (Temp: 34.8 ? C), no pallor, no jaundice, no cyanosis.    CNS: Fully conscious, able to talk, follows instructions slowly, oriented in time place and person. No features of meningeal irritation. Normal muscle tone and power, normal deep tendon reflexes.    Other Systems: Normal    Impression: 11- and 1/2-years with Focal Epilepsy (Left temporal lobe epilepsy)    Plan: 1. Tabs Carbamazepine 300 mg bd × 2/12  2. CT-Scan of the Brain

Has been on Levetiracetam 750 mg (am) 1000 mg (nocte) and Lamotrigine 50 mg od    Family Social History: 4th child of the parents. The 1st child had febrile seizures. Both parents are teachers. column14: 3-year-old/Male been unwell since 5/12 months of age when the child started convulsing; managed in hospital for an unknown illness but with less improvement. Father reports being admitted for 2/12 and discharged when the convulsions were much less in frequency but reportedly still occurred. He was discharged on Carbamazepine but early this year; he was switched to Sodium Valproate because seizures were poorly controlled (27.5 mg/kg) 5 ml bd in January 2022. Today: Father reports child has marked improvement as he has had only 2 convulsions since January 2022. He has delayed milestones and has no behavioural problems.   This is the 1st born of 2 children. The sibling is well. No history of epilepsy in the family.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), afebrile, no anaemia, no jaundice, no edema and no dehydration, not dysmorphic.    CNS: Active, reports to his name, ambulant with no focal neurology.    Noted EEG - Focal Epilepsy    Plan: 1. Syrup Epilim 5 ml bd × 3/12

column14: Presenting Complaint: Convulsions × 2 and 1/2 months  History of Presenting Complaint: 3 years 8/12 months old Female who was fairly well till 2 and 1/2 months ago when she developed left sided tonic clonic convulsions involving the left upper and lower limbs, no post ictal loss of consciousness, was started on Tabs Carbamazepine at 20 mg/kg but mother reports convulsions progressed and sometimes gets generalised convulsions involving both sides and sometimes involves only the right side. Currently child gets aura - She's able to anticipate the seizure attack but cannot explain what she sees. She gets about 0-5 episodes per day, lasts ~ 3-5 minutes.  Child has previously been managed for measles (intently has scaly itchy skin and has a wet cough)    No diarrhea or vomiting, no lower limb swelling and no chest pain.    Past Medical History: No other known chronic illnesses.  Currently on Carbamazepine 27.78 mg/kg/day (100 mg 8 hourly)   Not HIV exposed.    Natal: Delivered by SVD at preterm (28/40 Weeks) to a Para 2+0 with birth weight 2.3 kg, was admitted × 2/12, lost weight up to 0.? kg, developed an illness post Natally that was characterized by yellowing.     Prenatal: Pregnancy was uneventfully.    Immunisation: Reportedly missed some vaccines but mother cannot tell which?     Family Social History: 2nd born of 2 children, sibling 13-year-old female in Primary 7 who is well. No known familial epilepsy or seizure disorder. Mother - no longer works because of the child's illnesses, father - unknown age ~ (35-38) Brocker    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), Afebrile, no jaundice, no anaemia, no cyanosis, no clubbing, no edema, no lymphadenopathy and no dehydration. Has desquamation of the skin.    CNS: ?Microcephalic (no tape measure), low set ears.    R/S: Bronchial breaths bilaterally - Infrascapular area.     P/A: Normal    Noted EEG: Features of Focal Epilepsy (Right-central)    Imp: 1. Uncontrolled Focal Convulsions  2. Pneumonia    Plan: 1. Do Brain CT Scan  2. Continue Tabs Carbamazepine 100 mg 8 hourly × 2/52  3. Tabs Lamotrigine 12.5 mg od × 1/7, Tabs Lamotrigine 12.5 mg bd × 2/7, Tabs Lamotrigine 12.5 mg (am) 25 mg (nocte) × 2/7  4. Syrup Flucamox 25 mg bd × 3/7, 260 mg 8 hourly × 5/7

column14: 15-year-old Female from Nkumba, self-referral with  Presenting Complaint: Abnormal Movements  Noted child was first unwell at 9 years of age when she had what was described as a generalised seizures at school; was managed as malaria and had another seizure 3 weeks later. The mother witnessed this seizure - it was generalised tonic clonic seizures with associated abnormal eye movements and rolling of saliva with loss of consciousness, no loss of bladder or bowel control during that seizure. No history suggestive of aura. They then sought care at Butabika and an EEG was done on 18/01/2019 and the conclusion was generalised epilepsy (Typical childhood absence epilepsy), and she was started on Carbamazepine which she has taken for 3 years. No history of absent mindedness. The child is in Primary 7 in boarding school, she still gets abnormal movements sometimes involving the hands. She had poor adherence to her anti-epileptic medication and the matron at her school started keeping them for her. No history of associated skin lesions or problems with vision or headache.    Antenatal/Birth History: Born by SVD and cried immediately after birth. Perinatal history was generally unremarkable. Antenatal history also generally unremarkable.     Family History: Has poor performance in school 2nd and 3rd grade. No family history of epilepsy.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), afebrile, no anaemia, no jaundice, no cafe au lait spots and no port wine stains.    CNS: Fully conscious, no focal localising signs, no fasciculations, normal muscle power, tone and reflexes.    Systemic Exam: Normal    Imp: 15-year-old Female with a seizure disorder (Typical childhood epilepsy - diagnosed in 2019)    Plan: 1. Repeat EEG  2. Stop Carbamazepine  3. Start Sodium Valproate 250 mg bd × 1/12

column14: 6/M referred from Ward 11 where he was being managed as newly diagnosed epilepsy with Sodium Valproate 10 mg/kg.  The child has had several episodes of convulsion described as generalised tonic clonic convulsion by the mother. These convulsions were initially preceded by febrile illness. The febrile convulsion started at 3 years of age but by 4 years, the convulsions stopped. When he made 6 years, he started having afebrile convulsions and these have been generalised tonic clonic usually preceded by a loud noise, the mother also reports episodes of atonia where the child simply falls down.     No history of developmental impairment.     No history of significant past medical/surgical intervention.    The child was delivered at term, cried immediately, however mother reports that she laboured for 48 hours.    Growth and Development has been normal,     Immunisation: The child did not get the measles vaccine: The child is the first born of 3 children, currently in top class, has been performing well except the disturbance due to convulsions.    Today the main concern is the convulsion that have resumed despite adherence to Sodium Valproate.    O/E: GGC (Good General Condition), Afebrile, no pallor, no jaundice, no lymphadenopathy and well nourished.    CNS: Alert, active, interested in his environment, no focal neurological signs    P/A: Normal    R/S: Normal    Noted EEG: Repetitive epileptiform discharges; present in the left occipital region.    Impression: Focal Epilepsy    Plan: Tabs Carbamazepine (15 mg/kg) 150 mg bd × 1/12

column14: Presenting Complaints: Referred after discharge from Ward 11 with a diagnosis of Focal Epilepsy.    History of Presenting Complaint: Mother reports she had an uneventful pregnancy and birth of Angel, birth weight = 5+ kg, cried immediately had no postnatal illnesses or yellowing of the skin.  At 4 years old she developed right sided focal tonic clonic convulsions while at school in baby class - Mother was not present, but reportedly seizures involved the right upper and lower limb and clenched lips. This repeat 1-2 times per month, at 5 years (2016) EEG was done in Mulago but did not wait in the line in the neuroclinic but rather went to ACU (Acute Care Unit)/ Pharmacy where Sodium Valproate was prescribed, and they kept buying the drugs themselves and sometimes would pick the medicines from Kayunga Health Center - However convulsions were not well controlled. She continued getting the fits 1-2 times per month to 2 months.  A year ago, during a community education event by Butabika Hospital at their local convention, they were linked and enrolled in care there and child was maintained on Sodium Valproate 300 mg bd and Folic Acid 5 mg od, however mother noted psychotic features in the child which she linked to the medicines. She reduced the dose to 300 mg od then eventually stopped it × 8/12. When child developed persisted right sided focal tonic clonic convulsions × 3/7, was admitted on Ward 11 through ACU and managed as focal epilepsy on Carbamazepine with improvement, was discharged on Carbamazepine 400 mg bd, Paracetamol and Folic Acid. To do RFT's and Brain CT Scan to be reviewed in Neuroclinic with results. Had no convulsions since discharge. Attends physiotherapy. At a rehabilitation Centre in Kayunga. Had neuromuscular impairment sequelae post the previous discharge following the status epilepticus.    MSS: Mother is concerned that the right side is now shorter than the left.    ROS (Review of Other System): Unremarkable.    Immunisation: Completed    Growth and Development: Mother thinks child has been growing well, gaining weight normally as compared to children of a similar age, however had delayed milestones, crawling at 2 years, sitting at 1 year, speech (one word) at 3 years, currently in Primary 1. Exclusively breastfed for 6/12 months, stopped breastfeeding at 1 year.  Nutritional History: Currently on adult food, balanced diet with 3 meals a day.    Family Social History: 3rd born of 4 children. Siblings are a 23-year-old Male at University, a 16-year-old Male in Senior 4, and a 5-year-old Male in baby class, all well, no known family history of epilepsy or any other chronic illnesses.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), Afebrile, no jaundice, no anaemia, no cyanosis, no clubbing, no edema, no lymphadenopathy, no dehydration and good nutritional status.     MSE (Mental State Exam): Affect congruent with mood. Cognition is mildly impaired -does not give constructive conversation.  Memory is impaired -?? Retrograde Amnesia  Judgement??  Reasoning Impaired  Has episodes of uncoordinated speech    Systemic Examination: Normal    Noted results: Brain CT Scan: Features are suggestive of Corpus Callosum agenesis.  Recommendation: Brain MRI Correlation advised.    RFT'S   Crea - 64 umol/L (63.6 - 110)  Urea - 1.8 mmol/L (2.7 - 6.4)  Na+ - 148 mmol/L (135 - 150)  K+ - 4.97 mmol/L (3.5 - 5.5)  Cl - 111.2 mmol/L (95 -110)    Impression: 1. Focal Epilepsy secondary to Corpus Callosum Agenesis  2.? Psychosis    Plan  1. Counsel parents on diagnosis  2. Keep on Carbamazepine 400 mg bd × 1/12  3. Review by Paediatric Neurologist  4. Link to Occupational therapist  5. Avoid Sodium Valproate (Already pubertal)

column14: 6/M referred to us by the Neurosurgical team due to recurrent convulsions.  Diagnosed with right temporal arachnoid cyst surgery (Arachnoid cyst fenestration) done 7/12 ago.  P/C - Convulsions - 5 episodes of convulsions associated with a brief loss of consciousness, bowel and bladder control intact, no associated fevers.  ANC - Normal  Delivered, Elective C/S - 2PS, Birth Weight - 3.8 kg, cried immediately, did not require oxygen therapy.  Postnatal - Had excessive high pitch, cry at first 1/52 week of life, admitted × 2/52 in Nsambya, transfused and improved but by that time the head size was increasing; improved till at 5 years that he developed convulsions/sudden collapse with brief Loss of Consciousness, that the diagnosis made in Mulago and surgical intervention done. Child is currently in middle class and is performing well.  3rd child, sibling are okay.    O/E: Stable, good general condition, fairly large head with a recent surgical scar on the right temporal region - visible pulsation over the region, no anaemia, no jaundice and no dehydration.    CNS: Head Circumference - 54.3 cm, neck is soft, normal tone, neck soft and Kernig's sign negative.    Other Systemic Examination: Unremarkable    Impression: Temporal Arachnoid Cyst - Recurrent Seizures    Plan: 1. Levetiracetam 250 mg (am) 500 mg (nocte) × 2/52  2. Do EEG    Risk Factor: Diagnosed with right temporal arachnoid cyst surgery (Arachnoid cyst fenestration) done 7/12 ago.

column14: RE: Advised to come and open file in Neuroclinic after doing EEG.    History of Presenting Complaint: Ssebadduka reports he has been getting convulsions since 9 years of age, he reports this was proceeded by trauma to the head - a month earlier, was knocked down by a boda boda however he did not lose consciousness.  He reports he feels the seizure coming - feels like an electric shock then the right limb is contracted and flexes upward by the elbow joint, but he keeps aware, the seizure last ~ 1 hour, comes about once a month. Has not been on any medication since.    Review of systems: Unremarkable    Past Medical History: Reported to Paediatric, EEG requested showed - features of focal epilepsy, was started on Carbamazepine 200 mg bd then 300 mg bd × 2/12 and he reports he has not had any convulsion since then.    Family Social History: He is the last born of 5, siblings are well, no known family history of epilepsy. Went to school up to Primary 7, dropped out of school due to funds. Now does casual labour like fetching water.  Siblings 23-year-old Female in school, 24-year-old Male saloonist, he does not remember other. Lives with father - who works in a bar. Mother works in South Sudan as a saloonist with son.     O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), clinically stable.    CNS: No meningitis and no abnormal movement.    MSE (Mental State Exam): Good Cognition, poor memory, cannot remember his two other siblings' names and details    Impression: 18-year-old Male Late Adolescence secondary to Focal Epilepsy with Neurological Sequelae on Memory    Plan: Continue Tabs Carbamazepine 300 mg bd × 1/12

column14: Weight: 22.8 kg    Convulsions × 4 years  6/M who has had a febrile convulsion since the age of 2 years 8/12-month-old. The father reports that the convulsions are focal to bilateral generalised convulsions. Starting with the right leg spreading to involve both legs and the head. The seizures usually happen while in sleep or at waking up. There is also a history of intellectual impairment with poor school performance. The child has been in baby class for the last 3 years. No history of aggressive behaviour, has a normal sleep pattern.    The prenatal, natal and postnatal history is non-remarkable.    Immunisation was complete    Growth and Development: This has largely been normal, crawled at 8/12 months and talks normally. column14: Shama Bayiga  Weight: 13.3 kg    Developmental delay  Seizure × 1 year    3 years 3/12-month-old boy who has delivered by elective C/S due to 2 previous scars. Birth weight 2.5 kg cried immediately but after one hour, he developed seizures with excessive crying. Was admitted in the nursery for 3 days. He was able to sit without support by 5 months and was crawling by 7 months. He is however still unable to walk without support or stand unsupported. He however walks on objects. He developed unprovoked seizures 1 year ago seizure lasts about 3 minutes with post-ictal loss of consciousness and loss of sphincter control. He is not yet able to talk. Been on Tabs Carbamazepine from Butabika Hospital.     O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), afebrile, no anaemia, no jaundice, no edema and no cyanosis. Noted very light brown iris bilaterally. No dysmorphic features.    CNS: Has a broad-based gait on support, fully conscious and interactive. Neck soft, Kernig's negative. Pupil Equal and Reactive to Light. Normal tone and reflexes.    Other Systems: Normal    Noted EEG: Epileptic Encephalopathy (Feb 2022)    Imp: Global Developmental delay  Epilepsy    Plan: 1. Stop Carbamazepine  2. Tab Sodium Valproate 100 mg bd × 1/12  3. Tab Prednisolone 15 mg (am) 10 mg (pm) × 2/52  4. Do Physiotherapy

column14: 24/10/2022    9/12 months old Male came in with history of convulsions for 9 months. He was until he developed convulsion. Mother noted generalised tonic seizures with associated loss of consciousness. There is associated delay in developmental milestones (he is only sitting).    ROS (Review Other System):  Genitourinary System: Normal micturition habits     GIT: Poor appetite for food. He only drinks mainly black tea; juice, porridge  Other systems: Unremarkable    Past Medical History: He was on and off. Lamotrigine, Sodium Valproate and Levetiracetam 250 mg and Tegretol.  Prenatal History: Mother attended antenatal care 4 visit. She was given TT, IPT and Mebendazole. She was treated for UTI during pregnancy.    Perinatal history: Mother reported prolonged > obstructed labour done C/S after referral from attending clinic. Child did not cry immediately; he was resuscitated and gave a week cry. He was put on oxygen and at 2/7 day, he cried uncontrollably. He was initiated an unknown medication. The child later had generalised convulsions.    Developmental history: Smiled at 2 weeks, he has achieved sitting with support at nine months.    Family Social History: 5th born of 5 children, no family history of similar presentation. Receives social support from the father.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), Afebrile (Temp 37.2 ? C), no jaundice    MSK (Musculoskeletal System): Upper limbs and lower limbs have normal tone and reflexes.    CVS: Warm extremities, PR -101 bpm, normal JVP and Heart Sounds I + II heard.    RS: SPO2 98% on room air, RR - 24 bpm and bronchovesicular breath sounds.    Impression: Cerebral Palsy with Epilepsy.    Noted EEG done on 07/09/2022  An abnormal sleep record due to focal epileptiform discharges > focal epilepsy    Plan: 1. Syrup Sodium Valproate 5 mls bd × 2/52  2. Tabs Keppra 125 mg bd × 2/52  3. column14: 27/10/2022    2-years 1/12-month-old Male patient of with epilepsy on syrup Epilim; initially on Syrup Epilim 2 ml bd 5/7 then on Syrup Epilim 3 ml bd 7/7 and finally Tabs Sodium Valproate 200 mg bd 1/12.  He was well until 1-year 7/12 months old when he developed generalised tonic-clonic convulsions that lasted 2 minutes with associated loss of consciousness. He was managed in a peripheral clinic for malaria on duocotexine (unknown dosage). At 1-year 9/12-month-old he had another episode of convulsion. It was tonic convulsion associated with loss of consciousness, it lasted 3 minutes. Thereafter mother reported repeated convulsions everyday with increase in episodes (from 4-7 episodes per day) The convulsions were spontaneous and lasted 2-3 minutes. He has been repeatedly managed for probable malaria with different regimen. There was no associated aura. Gaining of consciousness was associated with inconsolable crying and irritability for 30 minutes.    ROS (Review of Other Systems)    GIT: Good appetite for solid and liquid foods, normal bowel habits.    GUT: Normal micturition habits, passes yellow coloured urine (4-6 times a day)    Other systems: Unremarkable.    Past Medical History: Patient with chronic convulsions? Because of tablets clonazepam (unknown dosage) and Epilim 200 mg bd 1/7.     An EEG done at MNRH 27/08/2022 reported relatively normal background with burst of generalised epileptiform activity - generalised epilepsy (? Doose syndrome).     Mother reported less convulsion 2-3 episodes a day at the point of initiation of regimen; upon increase of dose, the convulsions resided.    Prenatal history of 4 antenatal care visit, received TT vaccine, IPT and Mebendazole.    Perinatal history of spontaneous vaginal delivery, cried immediately and birth weight 3.3 kg    Post natal: Discharge immediately. Mother reported fine tremors in upper limbs and lower limbs which become worse during high grade fever.    Immunisation: UpToDate    Family Social history: 2nd born child of 2 children, first born is female - no convulsion and positive history of convulsions in the paternal aunt.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), afebrile, no pallor, no jaundice, birth weight 13.3 kg, SPO2 93% PR 60 bpm    CNS: He is alert, normal muscle tone and reflexes in upper and lower limbs.    P/A: Normal fullness, soft, non-tender, no organomegaly.    R/S: Bronchovesicular breath sounds.    Dx: 2 years 1/12-month-old Male with convulsion disorder?? Epilepsy (Doose syndrome)    Plan: 1. Tabs Clonazepam (0.03 mg/kg/day) ¼ ? od × 3/12  2. Tabs Sodium Valproate 200 mg bd × 3/12

column14: 03/11/2022    6/12-month-old baby, diagnosed with ventriculomegaly in utero and syrup Keppra  D/C - Abnormal movements since birth  -	Delayed milestones since birth    History of Presenting Complaints: Mother reports baby has had 'hugging movements' since birth, initially had several episodes but frequency has now reduced to 4-5 times/day, lasting 4-5 minutes and have no timing of day. Mother also reports baby has not attained any milestones since birth. Is also very floppy and always has excessive crying. Also, she noticed baby has no sight and eyes cannot follow mother's fingers. Right eye cannot open spontaneously. Baby breastfeeds well. Baby passes little stool but passes urine well. Currently has wet cough but no difficulty in breathing.    ROS (Review of Other System): Unremarkable    Past Medical History: Was admitted to NICU in Mulago Specialised Women and Neonatal Hospital × 9/7 day, managed with Intravenous fluid, antibiotics and CPAP and managed for neonatal jaundice × 3/7 with phototherapy.    Family Social History: Unremarkable    Natal History: Mother was booked at 4/12 months, attended antenatal care 3 times, received routine care. Was screened for HIV, Syphilis - Negative. Mother did an USS at 2/12 months old amenorrhea and was told she had inadequate liquor. Also did another at 33 WOA and baby was found to have ventriculomegaly. Was delivered at term by Emergency C/S, birth weight 3.5 kg, APGAR SCORE 6 (1minute) 7 (5 minutes), mother not sure if baby cried immediately.    Immunisation History: Up to date (No card)   Growth and Development: Has not attained any milestones.    Nutritional History: Exclusive breast-feeding for 6/12 months, mother has initiated on cow's milk    Family Social History: Last born of 3 children, the other siblings are alive and healthy. Parents stay together. Father is a driver. No family history of seizures/epilepsy.    O/E: Afebrile, no pallor, no jaundice, no dehydration, no lymphadenopathy and no dysmorphic features.    CNS: Head Circumference - 43.7 cm, anterior fontanelle is closed, has no head control, baby is floppy and has reduced deep tendon reflexes.    CVS: Tachycardia, Heart Sounds I + II heard. No murmurs.    R/S: Not in distress, equal air entry, chest clear.    Imp: ?Infantile Spasm   R/O West Syndrome    Plan: Urgent EEG to R/O West Syndrome  2. Continue syrup keppra 1 ml bd   3. If Hypsarrhythmia present, give high dose Prednisolone at 6 mg/kg/day for 4-6 weeks.    24/04/2023  1 year old Female child being managed for focal epilepsy currently on Carbamazepine. Mother missed review for 3 months now. Mother reported she has been buying medicine.  Today - mother reported child has been Intravenously treated (been on IV medicines)  -Currently child developed vomiting, no abdominal distention  -Mother reported episodes of seizures that have markedly reduced - 2 episodes a day and with no seizure other day.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition) not pale, no jaundice and well hydrated    CNS: Fully conscious, pupils equal and reactive to light    P/A: Normal fullness, soft and non-tender    Impression: Focal Epilepsy  Resolving Viral respiratory tract infection    Plan: 1. Encouraged mother to feed the child  2. PO Carbamazepine 50 mg (am) 100 mg (pm) × 3/12  3. PO Ondansetron 2 mg tds × 3/7    Risk Factors: Neonatal Jaundice  Ventriculomegaly diagnosed in utero

column14: 2 and ½ year old Male patient presented with history of convulsions for 1 year. Was well until 1 year of age when he developed generalised clonic convulsion. The convulsions last 4 seconds with a one-two episodes a month. There is associated loss of consciousness. There is no known trigger to the convulsions.     Review of Other Systems:    GIT: Good appetite and normal bowel sounds  GUT: Passes straw coloured urine 4 times a day  SKIN: Unremarkable    Past Medical History: Not on any chronic medication.    Pre-Natal: Attended 4 antenatal care visits: IPT, Mebendazole, TT Vaccines given.     Perinatal: She labored for 3 days. Had SVD (Spontaneous Vaginal Delivery) to alive baby boy and birth weight 3.8 kg.    Postnatal: Child cried immediately was pink.    Immunisation: Child was given routine vaccines up to 18 months (no card available)    Nutritional History: Exclusively breastfed for 6 months. Weaned on formula milk and fortified Soya Porridge.     Developmental history: Smile at 2 weeks, sat at 6 month and walked at 8 months.    Family-Social History: 1st born son of the family. Father died (July 2022) due to work related hazards.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition) Afebrile, no pallor and no jaundice. SPO2 99%, PR 118 b/min    MSS: Normal muscle tone and reflexes    CNS: Alert, pupils equal and reactive to light, no signs of meningeal irritation    P/A: Normal fullness, soft and non-tender    Impression: 2 years 1/12-month-old Male with Epilepsy    Noted EEG (07/09/20): Normal sleep record    Plan: 1. Tab Sodium Valproate 150 mg bd

column14: 03-11-2022    6-year-old Female from Kireka, Wakiso  Presenting Complaint: 1. Delayed Speech  2. Abnormal behaviour    6-year-old Female delivered at term by Spontaneous Vaginal Delivery, following uneventful labour and delivery, Birth Weight 3.2 kg, cried immediately. Developed on complications in neonatal period. Sat at 4-5 months however the grandfather noticed delayed milestones afterwards. Started to speak clear audible words at about 5 years, currently is able to say just a few words and construct 2-letter sentences. She was taken to school but is unable to write any constructive letters or words.   Grandmother has noticed abnormal behaviour including defecating anywhere and playing with children younger than her or playing alone. Sometimes she cannot respond to instructions. No history of fever or abnormal movements, no changes in sleep patterns. No reports of aggressive behaviour unless provoked.    ROS (Review of Other Systems): R/S, CVS and GIT - Unremarkable    Past Medical History/ Past Surgical History: Was admitted and managed for a skin rash at 1 month, no history of blood transfusion.  Immunisation history - Was fully immunised - (card available)    Nutrition History: Adequate in quality and quality.    Family Social History: Stays with maternal grandmother, she is the 1st born of the mother (only child). No history of chronic illness or mental illness in the two families.    O/E: Calm, sitting in one place, not destructive. Afebrile, no pallor and no jaundice. Offered a pen to write and refused to hold it; moved away to the grandmother. Has good eye contact, smile while greeted and responds with one word.     Other systems: Unremarkable    Noted EEG report: Abnormal sleep record due to focal epileptiform discharges suggestive of focal epilepsy.    Impression: 1. Focal Epilepsy  2. Intellectual Disability  Plan: 1. Tabs Carbamazepine 150 mg bd × 1/12  2. Review by Paediatric Psychiatrist

column14: 03/11/2022  Mayengo Bernard    6/M, known SCD with old stroke on Hydroxyurea, daily Folic Acid, monthly Fansidar on Carbamazepine and Sodium Valproate. Being managed for focal seizure.  Presenting Complaint: Stiffening at Left upper and lower limb × 6 years    History of Presenting Complaint: In 2016, he developed stiffening of the left upper and lower limbs with aura and post-ictal weakness. The seizures usually last 2 minutes but since reduction of carbamazepine in the last month, the duration has increased and now he falls down (drop attacks?) In the last 2/12-month months, has had 4 episodes.  Brain CT Scan (04-08-2022); Features at marked right cerebral hemi-atrophy and left temporal lobe chronic infarct with gliosis. Most likely due to ischaemic cerebral vasculopathy in the territory of the ICA and left MCA respectively.    He currently walks with a limp.    ROS (Review of Other Systems): Unremarkable    Past Medical History: Was diagnosed with SCA (Sickle Cell Anaemia) at 9 years of age. Has had 5 admissions. Last one was at Mulago due to stroke. No other known chronic illnesses.    Past Surgical History: Has had several blood transfusions. No surgeries.    Natal history: Mother was booked at 3/12 month and had several visits. Pregnancy was uneventful. Was delivered at term, by Spontaneous Vaginal Delivery, birth weight - 3.0 kg, cried immediately. Was managed for neonatal sepsis and discharged in good general condition.    Immunisation History: Completed vaccination  Growth and Developmental history: Attained milestones appropriately for age. Not in school since nursery because of illness.  Family and Social History: 2nd born of 3 children. 3rd sibling is also a Sickler. 1st sibling is alive and healthy. Both parents are alive and healthy. Mother is a teacher in Liberia. Father is a mechanic. No family history of epilepsy.    O/E: Afebrile, no jaundice, no anaemia, no dehydration, no lymphadenopathy, has an abnormal gait and posture.    CNS: Has flexion at the hip and knee joint, fully conscious, neck soft, has hypertonia of left lower limb, normal tone and power in right side, power 4 in left upper limb.    CVS: Heart Sounds I + II heard with no murmurs.    R/S: Not in distress, equal air entry and chest clear.    Impression: Sickle Cell Anaemia with focal epilepsy  H/o Stroke    Plan: 1. Tab Carbamazepine 200 mg (am) 300 mg (pm) × 2/52  2. Tab Sodium Valproate 500 mg bd × 2/52    Risk Factor: Sickle Cell Disease and Neonatal Sepsis, Stroke

column14: 27-10-2022    Kizito Enock  Age: 1-year 3/12 months old  Weight: 12.7 kg    Seizures × 6/12  Regression of milestones × 1/12    He was well till 6/12 ago when he developed a febrile illness managed as severe malaria. He had associated multiple seizures during the illness. He subsequently developed febrile seizures but no reported seizures when afebrile. However, 1/12 month ago, he was reportedly well and playing then suddenly fell down and developed multiple prolonged seizures associated with Loss of consciousness. He was admitted on Ward 11, multiple investigations done and was diagnosed with Dravet Syndrome (Severe myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy) and viral encephalitis. He was managed with IV acyclovir and Phenobarbitone then discharged on Syrup Sodium Valproate at 33 mg/kg/day with Cefixime and Ambrodil. Mother reports no improvement. He still gets breakthrough seizures and has regressed in milestones. He was initially able to walk on objects but he currently cannot sit without support. He was born normally, cried immediately and had achieved age-appropriate milestones till 9/12 months of age.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), febrile to touch (Temp: 37.9 ? C), no anaemia, no jaundice, no edema and no cyanosis. Noted unfocused gaze and drooling saliva. No dysmorphic features.    CNS: Conscious but drowsy, neck soft, Kernig's sign negative. Has generalised hypotonia.    R/S: Not in distress, equal air entry bilaterally with transmitted sounds. No rhonchi. Other systems - Normal.    Noted EEG: Focal to bilateral epilepsy (from discharge form with no EEG report)  Impression: Dravet Syndrome    Plan: 1. Increase the dose of Sodium Valproate  2. Tab Sodium Valproate 300 mg bd × 2/52
