column14: 08/01/2021    7-year-old Male sent in as referral from sickle cell clinic with diagnosis of 2 previous stroke and cortical blindness in a known SCA patient. Child was relatively well until 11 months ago, when he developed sudden abnormal gait. On taking him to hospital, he was diagnosed with sickle cell stroke affecting the left side. He was managed with blood transfusion, Oxygen therapy and physiotherapy with marked improvements.  In June of 2020 (9 months ago) the child was taken to theatre for ENT operation ?? choanal atresia, during this time he developed intractable seizures and went into coma. He was referred to Mulago where he was managed for stroke for a period of 3 months. During recovery it was noted that he had lost his sight, and the ophthalmology team diagnosed cortical blindness. He also had recurrent seizures and was unable to sit or walk and lost his speech.    Current management: - Physiotherapy  -Occupational therapy  -Speech Therapy  -Tabs Sodium Valproate, Baclofen  -Tabs Hydroxyurea, Fansidar and Folic Acid    Issues at the moment  -Gets Visual + Tactile hallucinations, not associated with onset of seizures  -Cognition and speech have improved  -Unable to sit and walk  -Sight: Appreciates light but not specific objects  -No seizures for the past 3/12 months    Family Social History: He is the 1st born, lives with both parents. Father is a math teacher and mother is a housewife. Both parents lost their jobs during the pandemic. Has 2 siblings who are both Sickle Cell Carriers.    O/E: Fair General Condition, active, afebrile, no anaemia, no jaundice, no dehydration, no edema, no lymphadenopathy. No abnormal behaviour    R/S: Not in distress. Chest is clear    CVS: Warm peripheries, capillary refill < 2 seconds, Heart Sounds I + II heard and normal    P/A: Normal    CNS: Alert, neck soft, has a contracture on the right elbow. Generalised hypertonia and generalised hyperreflexia. Increased Clonus.    Impression: 7-year-old Male with Sickle Cell Anaemia with bilateral stroke, Epilepsy secondary to stroke and cortical blindness    Plan: 1. Tabs Sodium Valproate 300 mg bd × 3/12  2. Continue physiotherapy + Speech therapy  3. To see ophthalmologist at the next visit  4. Continue Tabs Hydroxyurea, Fansidar and Folic Acid  5. Tabs Baclofen 10 mg od × 3/12  6. EEG at the next visit    Risk Factor: In June of 2020 (9 months ago) the child was taken to theatre for ENT operation ?? choanal atresia, during this time he developed intractable seizures and went into coma.

column11: Epilepsy with multifocal cortical Luminar necrosis in Left frontal parietal and occipital lobes.
column14: Numazi Shamirah    Age: 4 years 11/12 months old    Child was well till 1-year 6/12 months old when she started developing convulsions, generalised tonic Convulsions, no loss of consciousness, no urine or faecal incontinence. Caregiver reports child has had repeated episodes at least once per month and has been on treatment including Phenobarbitone; However, a month ago the convulsions worsened and was persistently admitted for ~ 2/52 weeks associated with left sided weakness and regression of milestones including inability to talk, walk and sit unsupported.    EEG (11/1/21) was done showing an abnormal routine awake/sleep EEG recording and consistent with severe left hemispheric cortical dysfunction. Was then started on Tab Sodium Valproate with much improvement; starting to regain the inability to talk.    CT scan (26/01/21) - Multifocal cortical luminal necrosis in the left frontal parietal and occipital lobes; most likely due to cerebral hypoperfusion. There is grade 2 global brain atrophy.    O/E: FGC (Fair General Condition), afebrile, no jaundice, no anaemia and no dehydration.    R/S: No distress, equal air entry bilaterally and chest is clear.    CVS: Heart Sound I + II heard with no added sounds and warm peripheries.    CNS: Alert, carried by mother, pupils equal and reactive to light, increased tone more on the right than the left, hyperreflexia with sustained clonus.    Impression: Epilepsy with multifocal cortical Luminar necrosis in Left frontal parietal and occipital lobes.    Plan: 1. Continue Tab Sodium Valproate 300 mg bd × 2/52

column14: 04/02/2021    11/M brought by mother with complains of  -Convulsions × 3 years    Was well until 3 years ago when he developed convulsions that started on the left and then involve the entire body. The seizure lasts ~ 2 minutes with post ictal drowsiness. No stool or urine incontinence. Seizures are preceded by extreme loss of energy and drowsiness. No history of fevers and no history of trauma to the head.  He has managed with herbal medication for 1 and ½ years with no improvement. He was then taken to hospital and given tablets (unspecified) that did not offer any help. Currently seizures are more frequent ~ 5 episodes per day.  No regression in milestones or cognition but school performance is affected because of absences due to illness.    Review of Systems: Unremarkable    Past Medical History: Has been admitted multiple times due to febrile illnesses. The last admission was two weeks ago. Currently not on daily medication.    Immunisation: Up to date    Birth History: Unremarkable  Had a swollen fontanelle + excessive crying in early neonatal period treated in hospital.    Growth and Development: Appropriate for age.    Family Social History: 6th child of 6 children. One sibling died at 9 months of age due to severe malaria.    O/E: Fair general condition, afebrile, no jaundice, no anaemia, no cyanosis, no clubbing and no dehydration.    R/S: Normal    CNS: Alert, well oriented, no abnormal behaviour noted and abnormal movements. Neck soft, normal tone and no focal neurological deficits noted.    P/A: Normal    CVS: Warm peripheries, capillary refill < 2 seconds, hearts sound I + II and normal  Noted EEG: Focal epileptiform activity detected bifrontally (Rt > Lt)    Impression: Focal Epilepsy    Plan: 1. Tabs Carbamazepine 300 mg bd × 2/52

column14: 11/02/2021  Alonyo Elijah    c/o convulsions × 2 years  2 years 3/12-month-old Male who has been unwell for 2 years with convulsions describes as child turns the neck, to one side, with an upward gaze of the eyes then later nodes the head once and drool saliva with loss of consciousness for ~ 5 seconds and failure to response to stimuli. Happens several times (>10 times)/day. Sleeps well. Seizures started at 3/12 months of age.    Mother reports associated development delay; not able speak, walk.  Child plays alone and poor social interaction    Review of other systems: Unremarkable    Past Medical History: No known chronic admissions. Has had recurrent respiratory tract infections, no history of admissions    Birth and Development: ANC - Mother had an uneventful pregnancy, had admission for hyperemesis gravidarum in early pregnancy. Received routine care and tested HIV seronegative. Delivered by SVD in a medical center, baby cried immediately, was not put on oxygen and the immediate neonatal period was uneventful. Baby was managed for pneumonia at 1/12 of age. Has had developmental delay and started sitting without support at 2 years of age.    Family Social History: 2nd born of 2 children; 1st child is 7 years old. Stays with both parents. Mother is a tailor, and father is a police officer.     O/E: In Fair General Condition, no anaemia, no jaundice, no dehydration and afebrile.  Weight: 13.9 kg    CNS: Alert, aphasic, neck is soft and hypertonia in the right limb    P/A: Normal fullness, soft, no palpable masses.    R/S: Not in distress, equal air entry and chest is clear    Impression: Epilepsy with Developmental delay  R/O Dravet Syndrome    Plan:   1.	Do EEG  2.	Physiotherapy  3.	PO Sodium Valproate 150 mg bd × 1/12 (20 mg/kg/day) after reviewing EEG results

At 5/12 months of age, mum noted child developed spasms when he had started sitting with support, associated with Neurological developmental delay and regression of motor development (stopped sitting), cannot hold objects in hands. Immunisation is UpToDate.    Family Social History: 4th born of 4 children. All other 3 siblings are well. No family history of epilepsy. Mother is a housewife; father is business man. column14: 18/02/2021    Presenting Complaint: Convulsions × 1/12    History of presenting complaint: 4 years old female who had been well until 1/12 month ago when she developed convulsions described as myoclonic jerks also shouting lasting ~ less than 1 minute. with full recovery of consciousness within that time, child developed generalised tonic clonic convulsions which lasted ~ 30 minutes > also loss of consciousness and drowsiness with generalised body weakness. The child also had a high-grade fever which was managed as severe malaria in a clinic and was admitted for 4/7 with recovery. Since then, the child has had several episodes of myoclonic jerks ~ 8 times a day. The child throws items held in hands but completely recovers. No associated loss of consciousness. Mother notices some jerks during sleep.    Review of other systems - Unremarkable    Past Medical History: Index episode of admission was when she developed convulsions and febrile illness. No history of blood transfusions/ surgical operations.    Birth/ Development/ Nutrition:    Antenatal Care: Attended antenatal care 4 times, pregnancy was uneventful, received routine care.    Birth: Delivered by Spontaneous Vaginal Delivery at Kawempe National Referral Hospital, at term neonatal period was unremarkable.    Achieved milestones on time.    Breastfed exclusively for 4/12 months, started mixed feeding and later weaned off at 8/12 months, currently feeds on family foods.    Immunisation: Missed measles vaccination.  Family Social History: 2nd born of 2 children, 1st born is 10 years and is well. No family history epilepsy. Has a positive family history of Sickle Cell Disease.    Weight: 15.1 kg    O/E: In FGC (Fair General Condition), fully conscious with frontal + parietal bossing, no anaemia, no jaundice, no dehydration, afebrile, dysmorphic features. Low set ears and high arch palate.    CNS: Alert, observed two myoclonic jerks , < 1s / drop attacks, neck is soft, normal tone, normal muscle bulk but no falls and no focal neurology.    R/S: Not in distress, equal air entry bilaterally and chest is clear.    CVS: Warm peripherals, capillary refill < 2 seconds, Heart Sound I + II + 0     P/A: Normal fullness, soft and no palpable masses.    Impression: 4-year-old Female - Epilepsy? Doose Syndrome    Plan: 1. Do EEG  2. PO Sodium Valproate 150 mg bd × 1/12  3. Review with results  4. Update measles vaccine

column51: 20/05/2021    EEG report (02/03/2021)  Prominent focal epileptiform discharges detected mostly in the left frontal and less in the left temporal areas (spikes). Features are of moderate cerebral dysfunction and focal epilepsy.    Reviewed 11-year-old male being managed for epilepsy on Sodium Valproate at 500 mg 12 hourly (25.6 mg/kg/day)  Mother reports: child is still having convulsions that are generalised tonic clonic convulsions that being as focal involving the left upper limb the gradually become generalised with loss of consciousness postictally. Child does not report any associated aura pre-ictally.  Convulsions usually occur about twice a month (beginning at the end of the month) but can last the whole day, with 30 minutes in between episodes and also at night. Last had a convulsion about 5 days ago.    O/E: Alert, well oriented in time, place and person, afebrile, no anaemia, no jaundice and no dehydration.    CNS: Alert (though sleepy), normal tone    Other systems: Unremarkable    Impression: Focal Epilepsy with moderate   cerebral dysfunction    Plan: Let's add Levetiracetam (to help control the seizures)  Start: 20 mg/kg/day Levetiracetam for 2 weeks then 40 mg/kg/day Levetiracetam for 2 weeks then review the child after 1 month, if seizures are not controlled then increase to 60 mg/kg/day.  Continue with Sodium Valproate at 25 mg/kg/day    Regimen: 1. Tab Sodium Valproate 500 mg 12 hourly × 1/12  2. Tab Levetiracetam 250 mg (morning) 500 mg (evening) × 2/52 then Levetiracetam 500 mg (morning) and 1000 mg (evening) × 2/52

column14: C/o Stiffening of the body and limbs, Repetitive convulsions, failure/ inability to sit    HPC: Reviewed Kasirye, 1 year and 1 week old/M, 3rd in the family of 3, other siblings healthy. Mother reports that the conception was planned, and she attended ANC, booked at 2 months, with unknown number of visits and pregnancy was uneventful. No serious ill health carried the pregnancy to 7 and half months and had acute onset of labor pain and delivered by SVD from Kibubbu HC III, baby didn't cry immediately and was on oxygen for 2 hours soon after delivery. Birth weight - 1.4 Kg. She was discharged home after 3 days, started breastfeeding, complemented at 6th month. She followed the immunization schedules up to date, however, she reports her baby was crying abnormally after attaining 6 weeks of life. She went to Naguru Hospital, where she was told her baby had Hernia and had problems seeing but was given another review date on 27/01/2021, eye review shows - light perception but can't follow hence Cortical Blindness. Child to benefit from physio and Chlorox. She also reports that her child underwent an operation to repair the Hernia from Naguru around May 2020.   However, she reports lately her child has about 5 episodes of fits in a day and there is stiffening of the limbs. She can only sit with support, and stand with support, recognises her mother but is unable to talk, has no audible syllables, and smiles and laughs when her mother plays with her. Has reduced oral intake, refers to both liquid and solid feeds and takes only a little.  She was delivered by SVD unassisted at a facility where she had gone to do a U/S at term. The baby was delivered after a few minutes of labour pain with the cord around the neck. Baby didn't cry immediately. Before that, she had been given intravaginal pessaries to induce labour.  Reports history of febrile illness and treatment for UTI around the time of delivery. Following delivery, she was referred to Naguru Hospital and managed for 2 weeks on Oxygen therapy.  She had convulsions and poor feeding but was later discharged a fair condition and advised to return for review after which she started attending physiotherapy and occupational therapy.    Review of Other Systems: - Unremarkable    Past Medical History: - was told that baby got tired leading to delayed milestones but no documentation of Cerebral Palsy diagnosis.    Past Surgical History: - Unremarkable.    Immunisation History: - Up to date    Nutritional History: - Breastfeeding since birth, introduced with other feeds at 6 months but refused most of the meals.    Family Social History: - 5th born out of 5 pregnancies, 4 children delivered but the 3rd child passed away due to an unknown illness., other siblings are alive and in good health.     On Examination:    General: FGC, breastfeeding well, microcephaly, afebrile, no jaundice, no anaemia, dehydration.    Central Nervous System (CNS): Alert, neck soft, hypertonia of the upper limb left greater than right. Hypotonic of the lower limbs    R/S: - Not in distress, chest is clear.    CVS: - PR-98b/m, HS 1+HS 2+0 heard and normal.    Impression: Post HIE Sequelae. R/O seizures Disorder.   Plan:  1.	Do EEG.  2.	Refer to Cerebral Palsy Clinic  3.	R/V with Results.

column14: Date: 25/03/2021  Weight: Not noted    A 2-year-old male brought by both parents with complaints of convulsions for the past four months. The child was previously well until four months ago when he experienced his first seizure, characterized by sudden head drops. Over time, parents observed generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting approximately 30 minutes, accompanied by postictal stool and urinary incontinence, followed by drowsiness.  •	No clear history of aura before seizures.  •	No fever, vomiting, or behavioral changes were associated with the episodes.  •	Developmental regression noted, with the child becoming unable to speak or walk.  •	No abnormal movements reported.  •	The child has been on sodium valproate 200 mg OD for two weeks with no improvement in condition.  •	Seizures have increased in frequency since symptom onset.    Review of Systems (ROS): Unremarkable    Past Medical History (PMH):  Admitted three times:  1.	As a neonate with breathing difficulties.  2.	Twice due to convulsions, the last admission being four months ago.  No known chronic illnesses.    Past Surgical History (PSH): Unremarkable    Birth History:  Born at term via SVD. Developed breathing difficulties at two weeks of age.    Growth and Development:  Initially age-appropriate, but developmental regression occurred after seizure onset.    Family and Social History (FSH):  Second of two children.  Elder sibling alive and well.  Positive family history of epilepsy on the paternal side.    On Examination (O/E):    General Condition: FGC  Post-Seizure State: Child had a seizure in the waiting area.  Vital Signs: Temperature: 36.9°C    Central Nervous System (CNS): Alert, soft neck, pupils equal and reactive to light, normal tone and power in all limbs.    Gait: Stepping gait; takes a few steps but bends forward when made to stand.    Respiratory System (RS): Not in distress; chest clear.    Cardiovascular System (CVS): Warm peripheries, capillary refill time <2 seconds, heart sounds 1 and 2 normal.    Per Abdomen (P/A): Normal findings.    Impression:  •	Generalized epilepsy  •	Epileptic encephalopathy  •	Rule out epilepsy syndrome    Plan:  1. Perform EEG.  2. Based on EEG results, consider a CT scan.  3. Start sodium valproate 150 mg BD for two weeks.  4. Next clinic appointment (TCA): 08/04/2021.

column14: Date: 12-04-2021    Complaints: Flu (after discharge from Ward 11, 2 months ago)    Current Medication: Carbamazepine 8 mg/kg/day for 8 months    Presenting Illness:  Is a review after discharge from Ward 11, 2/7 days ago. The child, a known patient with CP and epilepsy, has been on carbamazepine for 8 months and was stable until a febrile illness that required admission. The child was diagnosed with septicemia and status epilepticus.   The patient was born by spontaneous vaginal delivery (SVD) in Kisenyi HC II, did not cry immediately after birth, and was referred to the Special Care Unit (SCU) at KNRH. His birth weight was 3.9 kg. There was no history of prolonged labor or premature rupture of membranes (PROM), and labor lasted approximately 5 hours (? Precipitate labor).   The child was admitted to the hospital for 2 weeks and discharged in good condition. Initially, he was unable to breastfeed but was later breastfed with expressed milk until 6 months of age.  At 6 months, the mother noticed developmental delays, which prompted seeking medical help. Milestones included smiling at 2 months, rolling over at 1 year, and sitting with support after physiotherapy. The child can hear and see moving objects but had a seizure at 1 year and 1 month, which led to the diagnosis of CP, and carbamazepine was started.    Past Medical History (PMHX):  Admitted three times: First in SCU, last two admissions in Ward 11.  Currently on daily carbamazepine and attending physiotherapy with home visits.    Family/Social History (FSHX):  Last of three children; all siblings are healthy.  Lives with both parents and siblings.  Mother stays at home since the child became ill.  Father is a shop attendant and is supportive.    On Examination (O/E):    General: Fair, afebrile, (JACCOLD)0 Drooling Present, purposeless lip movements    Neurological: Increased tone in all limbs, hyperreflexia    Abdomen (P/A): Normal fullness, soft, non-tender, non-palpable    Respiratory (R/S): Chest clear, nasal congestion    Other Findings: No significant findings  Impression: Common cold in a child with Cerebral Palsy and Epilepsy    Plan:  1.	Normal Saline Drops  2.	Carbamazepine 50 mg BD × 1/12  3.	Ambroxol Syrup

column14: Date of Visit: 12/08/2021  Weight: Not provided  Age: 3 years old    A three-year-old male who has been relatively a normal child until about four months ago when he developed, when he was involved in a road traffic accident, he fell off a boda and sustained blunt head trauma and he immediately had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He had initially been managed on non-specific medications upon which he regained consciousness with no abnormal features. He had then several episodes about one week apart. After that episode, he was then started on oral carbamazepine 13.3/kg/day, which he has taken for about one month. However, over this one month, the mom reports that the generalized tonic-clonic seizures resolved, but the child started to have episodes of falling upon which he does not lose consciousness and is able to get up by himself. These can occur up to six times in a day and there is no history of muscle stiffness at night.    Review of Systems:  RS: No history of runny nose or cough.  GIT: No history of diarrhea or vomiting.  CNS: No history of easy fatigability.    Past Medical History:  Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections (URTI). No history of chronic illnesses. No previous admissions.    Family and Social History:  Lives with grandmother. Second child of the mother. Mother: Out of the country. Father: Deceased (RTA, 2 years ago). Caretaker reports hyperactivity.    Nutrition: Adequate in both quantity and quality.    Immunization: Up to date.    Natal History: Delivered by Spontaneous Vaginal Delivery (SVD).    Antenatal, perinatal, and postnatal periods were unremarkable.    Growth and Development: Age-appropriate developmental milestones achieved.    On Examination (O/E):    General Condition: Fair, Afebrile (A0), old scar with induration on the forehead.    CNS: Alert, normal muscle power, tone, bulk, and reflexes.    Impression:  Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS)    Plan:  1. Sodium Valproate 125 mg BD × 2/12  2. TCA: 16/09/2021    Main Risk Factors: Trauma to the head

column14: Index visit  Date of visit: 09/07/2020    A six-month-old infant was brought by the mother with a history of seizures that reportedly started during the neonatal period. Child flexes the arms and legs for two minutes with drooling of saliva. Experiences several episodes during the day, associated with loss of consciousness.    Born by emergency C-section due to cervical dystocia. Did not cry immediately after birth; birth weight was 3.15 kg. Resuscitated at birth and admitted to the special care unit for three weeks, where convulsions occurred.    Milestone delays noted:  Sat with support at four months.  Currently unable to sit without support or reach for objects.    Immunizations are up to date.    First child of the mother; mother is a hairdresser, and father is a barber.    On examination: FGC: Afebrile, fisting of hands, no dysmorphic features.    Respiration: Not in distress; chest is clear.    CNS: Fully conscious, normal muscle bulk, increased tone in all limbs, hyperreflexia in all limbs.    Review of systems: Unremarkable.    Impression: Spastic quadriplegic CP with seizure disorder.    Plan:  1. Do EEG.  2. Mother counseled on diagnosis and prognosis.  3. Syrup Sodium Valproate 25 mg BD × 1/12  4. Review in one month.  5. TCA: 06/08/2020    Date of visit: 12/03/2021  Patient's age: 1 year and 2/12 months  Patient's weight: Not recorded    Known patient of epilepsy on sodium valproate. CNS: Alert, active, PEARL, hypertonia of all limbs.    Respiration: Not in distress; chest is clear.    CVS: Heart sounds 1 + 2 are normal, no added sounds.    Abdomen: Normal fullness, soft, no palpable organs.    Impression: Multifocal epilepsy    Plan:  1. Tabs sodium valproate at 28 mg/kg/day, 125 mg BD × 2/12  2. TCA: 22/04/2021

column14: Date of visit: 20/07/2020  Patient's weight: 29 kg  Patient's age: Nine years  Height: 139.3 cm    A nine-year-old male presented with a history of recurrent seizures for two years, worsening in frequency in the last three months.  Describes the seizures as generalized tonic-clonic with loss of consciousness, occurring more than ten episodes a day, each lasting about one to two minutes.  No associated frothing, urine, or fecal incontinence.  Reports no associated fevers or headaches.    Review of systems:  No cough or difficulty in breathing.  Normal urine and bowel habits.    Birth history:  Father is unsure of the birth circumstances but claims the child was delivered at term by SVD, birth weight 3.0 kg, cried spontaneously.  He was well until the current illness.    Past medical history:  Never been admitted.  Unknown HIV sero-status.  No known food or drug allergies.    Immunization history:  Up to date.    Growth and development:  Achieved milestones appropriately.  Currently in P3, doing well in class.    Family social history:  Last born of three siblings, all doing well in school. Stays with both parents; mother is a housewife, and father is a mechanic. No known family history of epilepsy.    On examination:    General condition: Fair, with healing bruises on the face, afebrile (36°C), no anemia, jaundice, or dehydration.    Vitals: Respiratory rate 20/min, pulse rate 92/min, SpO2 99%.    CNS: Fully conscious, alert, neck soft, Kernig negative, PEARL, good muscle bulk, tone, and reflexes.    R/S: Lungs clear.    CVS: Normal heart sounds (1+2+0).    P/A: Normal fullness, soft, non-tender, no organomegaly.    EEG: Features of idiopathic generalized epilepsy.    Plan:  1. Start anti-epileptic drugs: PO sodium valproate 250 mg BD × 2/52  2. Review in two weeks (03/08/2020).

column14: Date of visit: 13/07/2020  Patient's weight: 17.2 kg  Presenting complaint: Seizures for 7 months    A 3-year and 7-month-old female has been having episodes of seizures since the age of 3 years.  Child appears as if she is not aware of the surroundings, starts to slowly but repeatedly blink her eyes as she turns her head to one side.  She does not fall down, and there is no jerky movement of the limbs.  Initially, she was not incontinent, but now she passes urine during the episodes.  Mother reports several episodes (greater than 10 times) per day, every single day.  Sometimes she says uncoordinated words during the episodes or tugs at her clothes, but other times, it's just the eye blinking.  There is a family history of epilepsy on the paternal side.    Prenatal and natal history:  Pregnancy was normal.  Delivery was by C-section due to failure to appreciate fetal heart sounds; however, the child cried immediately after birth, and the neonatal period was normal.    Growth and development: Normal.    Note: The child has been getting local hubs since the start of the seizures, which the mother reports has worsened the seizures.    EEG was done on 10/07/2020, and carbamazepine was started then.    EEG reports:  Epileptiform activity in the left parietal region, with a tendency to spread towards the left temporal area and generalized.    Impression: Focal epilepsy.    Plan:  1. Continue PO carbamazepine (started 3 days ago).  2. Bridge with levetiracetam (due to frequent seizures) and taper it off after two weeks, continuing only with carbamazepine.  3. Mother to look out for skin rash.    Treatment:  1. PO carbamazepine 100 mg BD × 2/52  2. PO levetiracetam 250 mg (PM) 125 mg (AM) × 2/52  TCA: 27/07/2020

column14: Date of Visit: 21/10/2021  Patient's Weight: Not provided    3-year-old male brought to the by the mother with a history of convulsions. Initially the first episode started in 2019 when the child was 1 year of age, then subsided but recurred in 2020 but has been persisted since then, having approximately 3 episodes every day. The convulsion is generalized tonic-clonic in nature, each episode lasting approximately 5 minutes, no history of aura, no urinary incontinence, no frothing. However, reports history of loss of consciousness and sleep post-ictal, was delivered at term by SVD, cried immediately perinatal history was uneventful, however had delayed milestones, started sitting at 6 months, crawling at 9 months, currently standing with support, can't talk, only make sounds, responds to his name. column14: Index Visit    Date of Visit: 04/11/2021  Age: 6 months old    A 6-month-old male, delivered at term to a para 1+0 mother with a birth weight of 2.2 kg (twin 1, 2.2 kg). The patient cried immediately at birth but developed convulsions at 24 hours of life. He was admitted for one week and treated with improvement. Seizure-free until 4 months of age, then experienced clustered seizures involving the eyes and trunk. Seizure frequency increased to several times a day by 6 months, prompting care-seeking.  An EEG performed on 13/09/2021 revealed a hypsarrhythmia pattern. He was started on high-dose prednisolone for two weeks, with improvement noted (seizure episodes reduced to 1-0 per day). A follow-up EEG showed resolution of hypsarrhythmia. column14: Date of Visit: 04/01/2019  Patient's Weight: 7.5 kg    C/O: Unable to sit without support, crawl, walk, chew solid food (long-standing).   Previously convulsing approximately 5 times daily with tonic-clonic seizures, eye rolling, and loss of consciousness. The seizures reduced significantly but reappeared in 2017. Initially controlled on carbamazepine, but poor adherence due to financial constraints led to missing treatment for over a year. Seizures resumed, presenting as tonic with eye rolling, occurring three times daily, along with swelling of feet requiring hospital admission. No associated fever. Restarted medication on 14/11/2018 and has since been seizure-free.    Developmental History: Smiles socially, turns his head when called, but feeding is slow. Unable to sit, crawl, walk, or hold objects firmly.    Prenatal/Natal History: Uneventful pregnancy. No fever, no measles-like rash, received vaccines. Delivered in New Mulago by SVD after approximately 12 hours of labor. Liquor was clear, but he did not cry immediately and required nursery care, oxygen, and antibiotics. No exposure to alcohol or tobacco.    Immediate Postnatal Period: Difficulty breastfeeding, weak, excessive sleep, minimal crying, and poor swallowing. No history of jaundice. Developed afebrile seizures at one week of age, persisting to date.    Immunization History: Up to date.    Growth and Development: Initially attempted to say "mama" and "tata" but regressed. Showed improvement with physiotherapy but regressed when sessions were missed.    Family/Social History: Mother is a housewife, father is a builder. Sharif is the fifth of six children. One sibling died at one year due to an unclear illness with similar weakness; another died as a neonate due to severe birth asphyxia and PROM. Three siblings (15-year-old male, 6-year-old female, 3-month-old male) are alive and well. The 15-year-old is not in school due to financial constraints. No family history of epilepsy or sickle cell disease.    O/E: FGC: Afebrile, A0 J0 D0, DEH2O0    CNS: Alert, normal eye movements, very minimal limb movements, spastic quadriplegia    R/S: No signs of respiratory distress, chest clear    CVS: Normal heart sounds 1 and 2    P/A: Soft, non-tender, no palpable organomegaly    Impression:  1. Global developmental delay  2. Seizure disorder  3. Spastic quadriplegia  4. Cerebral palsy secondary to HIE    Plan:  1. Continue Tabs Carbamazepine 50 mg BD x 1/12  2. Tabs Baclofen 2.5 mg BD x 1/12  3. Physiotherapy  4. Feed in CP chair regularly  5. Do EEG when funds are available  6. TCA 11/02/2019    Main Risk Factors: Perinatal asphyxia, possible family history of epilepsy

column14: Date of Visit: 28/01/2019  Patient's Weight: 12.8 kg    1 year and 2 /12 old male referred from the CP clinic with a complaint of delayed developmental milestones and seizures x 1 year. Mother reports that the child first developed seizures at the age of 1 month. The seizures are generalized tonic-clonic, associated with loss of consciousness (LOC), and used to last greater than 20 minutes, with no loss of sphincter control. Up to now, the child is unable to sit without support and has no words but smiles occasionally.   Immunization is reportedly up to date. The child was delivered by emergency cesarean section due to a delayed second stage of labor. He did not cry immediately at birth and required admission and oxygen therapy for 3 weeks in the SCU. He has been receiving physiotherapy at the CP clinic in Mulago. The child has been started on Carbamazepine 50 mg BD and Baclofen 2 weeks ago, and seizures have subsided.    O/E: FGC: Afebrile, A0 J0 D0    CNS: Fully conscious, active, with abnormal posturing and flexion of the limbs, increased tone, and reduced power.    R/S: Not in distress, chest clear.    CVS: Heart sounds 1 and 2 normal, no murmurs.    P/A: Non-tender, fullness soft, no masses.    Impression:  1.	Child with neurological sequel of HIE  2.	Global neurodevelopmental delay  3.	Spastic quadriplegia  4.	Focal epilepsy    Plan:  1.	Tabs Carbamazepine 50 mg BD x 1/12  2.	Tabs Baclofen 2.5 mg OD x 1/12  3.	Continue physiotherapy from CP Clinic  4.	Review on 25/02/2019

column14: Date of First Visit: 04-02-2019    6 years / male, C/O: convulsions, ×2/12, right hemiparesis.   Referred from Soroti RRH with epilepsy. He is a known epilepsy patient who was on carbamazepine for 3 years from a health centre III. He used to have astatic seizures that started at 2.5 years of age. He would suddenly collapse for about a minute and have urine incontinence. These were managed with carbamazepine and were well controlled.  Mother stopped medication 2 months ago, and the child developed generalized tonic-clonic convulsions. These would happen only during sleep, about 4 episodes a day, each lasting less than 1 minute. He also developed right-sided weakness, failure to speak, and drooling saliva. He has been on IV phenobarbital for 1 week, and the seizures have stopped.    Past Medical History: Unknown HIV sero-status, no other known chronic illness.    Past Surgical History: Surgery for a swelling at the back of the head at 2 years, no documents.    Natal History: Born at Tum by SVD, BWT: 3 kg. Cried immediately. Well in the neonatal period. Mother reports pregnancy was uneventful.    Growth & Development: Attained milestones at the right ages-sitting at 4 months, walking at 1 year. However, had regression of milestones associated with this sickness.    Family & Social History: Third born of 4 children. Other siblings are well. Lives with both parents. No history of epilepsy in the family.    Investigations: Brain CT scan normal. EEG correlates with epileptic encephalopathy. Abnormal sleep EEG shows multifocal epileptiform discharges.    Impression: Multifocal epilepsy.    Plan:  1.	Tabs Carbamazepine 100 mg BD ×2/52  2.	Syrup Sodium Valproate 75 mg BD ×2/52  3.	Physiotherapy  4.	TCA 18/02/2019

column14: First Entry (11/03/2019)  Patient's Weight: 26 kg  Age: 7 years    Presenting Complaint: Abnormal movement of the right hand for 1 year.    A 7-year-old female presents with abnormal movement at night in the right hand, characterized by myoclonic jerks. These episodes are also associated with head and eye movements to the right at night (? pre-ictal phase). Each episode lasts approximately 1 hour. Post-ictally, she is very weak and sleeps deeply. No enuresis is reported. Episodes occur twice a day but may disappear for up to a month before recurring. Mother reports serious learning difficulties in all aspects; she can hardly count. However, she is able to play with friends.    She was born at term and cried immediately after birth but had a febrile illness at 5 months of age with focal convulsions affecting the right side. No skin lesions are noted.    She was breastfed exclusively for 6 months and is now on an adult diet.    Mother attended antenatal care and received usual medications. No other significant history is reported.  Mother denies any family history of epilepsy.    O/E: A⁰J⁰D⁰C⁰. Alert, able to obey commands.    CNS: Normal tone, power, and reflexes in all muscle groups. Normal gait and posture.    P/A: NAD.    Chest: RR 15 breaths/min, vesicular breath sounds.    Noted Investigation: EEG suggests frontal epilepsy.    Plan:  1. Start Carbamazepine 200 mg BD for 1 month.

column14: First Entry (18/03/2019)  Patient's Weight: 13.8 kg  Age: 4 years    A 4-year-old girl with focal left-sided tonic-clonic convulsions, occurring mostly at night, lasting more than 30 minutes, and occurring approximately twice a year.  The age of onset was at 2 days of life, with no association with fever or pre-ictal phenomena.  Post-ictally, she experiences excessive sleepiness and generalized body weakness but later resumes activity and plays with friends.  Her mother reports that she was born at term, had an afebrile seizure at 2 days of life, and was delivered via SVD. She had speech delay but later caught up after a change of environment.  She is currently in Primary 4 and performs fairly well in school.  Her mother reports having had a seizure early in childhood, but it did not recur.    O/E: A⁰J⁰D⁰. Temperature 36.9°C, HC 46 cm,     CVS: RR 16 bpm, PR 94 bpm, HS1+2 normal.    CNS: Alert, able to communicate, increased tone in the right upper and lower limbs.  Power: 3/5 in the right upper limb, 4/5 in the right lower limb. Reflexes: Normal.    Investigations:    CT Scan: Left temporal and parietal lobe atrophy, gliosis, and atrophy.    EEG: Left parietal focal epilepsy.    Impression: Focal epilepsy secondary to structural problem.    Plan:  1.	Carbamazepine 50 mg (AM) 100 mg (PM) × 2/12   2.	Physiotherapy  3.	TCA on 20/05/2019    Main risk factor: Gliosis in the left temporal and parietal lobe

column14: First Entry (10/09/2020)  Patient's Weight: 41.2 kg  Age: 10 years    A 10-year-old female presenting with sudden falls for 3 years and seizures for 1 year.  Previously a healthy girl, she had unprovoked seizures 3 years ago. The history surrounding the seizures is unclear since they occurred while she was at school. However, her mother reports that she blacked out suddenly and was placed on herbal medications for about 1 year. During that time, the seizures resolved but later returned with a focal onset.  Her awareness is not impaired initially, but she later loses consciousness. The seizures are not associated with fever. She had one episode of a generalized tonic-clonic (GTC) seizure, which was associated with drooling of saliva and urinary incontinence.  She experiences these episodes approximately once per month, and they are now more frequent.  She is the second twin, had a low birth weight of 1.3 kg, but there was no birth asphyxia or neonatal jaundice. She has been very active, has grown well, and attained age-appropriate milestones with no speech delay.  She is currently in Primary 5 and performs fairly well in school.    PMH: No known medical illnesses, not on any medications. She was previously started on Sodium Valproate 250 mg OD for 3 months, but her mother reports that the attacks have persisted.    Personal/Social History: No significant history.    FSH: Third-born. Stays with mother and siblings. Father is separated. Mother is a journalist working at a radio station in Hoima    O/E: FGC, J⁰A⁰C⁰C⁰O⁰L⁰D⁰, afebrile, good nutritional status, pubertal.    CNS: Fully conscious and oriented, obeys commands, PEARL, no focal neurologic deficits.    R/S: Not distressed, normal air entry bilaterally, normal bronchovascular breath sounds.    CVS: PR 85 bpm, regular, normal volume, HS1+2 normal, no murmurs.    P/A: Soft, no organomegaly.    Imp: Generalized childhood epilepsy.    Plan:  1. Sodium Valproate 250 mg BD × 1/12   2. TCA on 12/10/2020

column14: First Entry (25/03/2019)  Patient's Weight: 12.2 kg  Age: 3 years    C/O: Vomiting for 1/52, constipation for 4/12, fever for 1/12, seizures since 2½ years of age.  The child has had seizures since birth. In the video shown, she exhibits clonic seizures preceded by an aura of screaming without loss of consciousness but with a blank stare. She has never been on any medication since her seizures started.  Now at 3 years old, she has experienced regression in milestones. Initially, she was able to sit, but now she cannot sit. However, she can still recognize her mother. The regression involves both motor and cognitive milestones.  The mother also reports constipation for about 4 months, current vomiting, and on-and-off fevers. The child is not able to chew food and is fed on mashed food.    CVS: Normal     Anogenital: Normal.    PMH: Has not sought care for long-standing seizures.    Immunization: Up to date.    Growth & Development: Has had regression in milestones. Initially able to sit, recognize her mother, and start crawling, but now unable to do so.    ANC: No antenatal care. Delivered at home. Cried immediately after birth. No complications associated.    FSH: Firstborn of two children. Younger child is 1 year old and well.    O/E: Good nutritional status, afebrile, J⁰C⁰D⁰.    R/S: Not in distress, good air entry.    CNS: GCS 15/15, fully awake but disoriented, hypotonic, no focal neurological deficits, no meningeal irritation signs elicited.    P/A: Tender hypogastrium, palpable mass in the lower abdomen.    Imp: ?Epileptic syndrome, ?West syndrome, ?R/O inborn errors of metabolism, ?Constipation with stool impaction, ?R/O masses.    Plan:  1.	EEG  2.	CBC  3.	Abdominal ultrasound scan  4.	Lactulose syrup 2.5 ml 8 hourly for 1 week  5.	Consider high enema with surgical consult and await EEG results    Main Risk Factors: Home delivery

column14: Date of Visit: 11/04/2019  Patient's Weight: 26.8 kg    History: 9-year-old male with a history of convulsions for 4 years. The child was well until 4 years ago when he developed generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting about 10 minutes. The child experiences recurrent episodes daily, with two episodes per month associated with frothing, tongue biting, loss of urinary sphincter control, drowsiness, and post-ictal period.  The mother reports that the child has become angrier since the onset of seizures, with no other abnormal behaviors. There has been a deterioration in school performance. The child complains of frontal headaches and reddening of the eyes just before seizures.  Born by SVD, cried immediately. Birth weight: 4.0 kg. Mother had precipitated labor lasting only 1 hour. ANC attended at Kawala, several visits. Mother tested HIV negative.  Mother was managed for syphilis during pregnancy; no other complications. No neonatal admissions. Underwent eye surgery at 6/12. Normal growth and development.   No developmental delay.  Fully immunized.  Last born in a family of six. Other siblings are healthy. No history of chronic disease. No family history of epilepsy.    O/E: FGC, Afebrile, J A D⁰. Hyperpigmented lesions on the right side of the face, less than 2 mm.    CNS: Alert, active, neck soft, Kernig's negative, no focal neurological deficits.    CVS: HR 85, HS 1+2+0.    P/A: Normal fullness, soft, no palpable   organs.    Resp: Not in distress, clear breath sounds.    EEG findings:  Diffuse slow waves mixed with quasi-spike waves. Noted high voltage 1-2 seconds, 3 Hz generalized typical spike wave hypersynchronies.    Conclusion: LGS, R/O focal diencephalic/mesencephalic lesion.    Imp: 9-year-old male with LGS.    Plan:  1.	Stop carbamazepine.  2.	Start sodium valproate at 15 mg/kg = 200 mg BD x 2/52.  3.	Tab phenobarbitone 15 mg OD x 2/52, tapering to stop.  4.	Consider doing contrasted CT scan or MRI to review R/O mesencephalic/diencephalic lesion and hypothalamic hamartoma on next review.

column14: A 4-year-old with gross developmental delay (inability to walk, sit, talk). The child has been attending the physiotherapy unit at Katalemwa Center when she developed repetitive generalized tonic-clonic convulsions. She was admitted on Ward 11 and managed for GTC with phenobarbitone and carbamazepine, which had been started at Katalemwa. The child was admitted on 4/05/19 and discharged on 10/05/19. Since discharge, the child has not had a convulsion and is currently on 15 mg phenobarbitone and 200 mg carbamazepine once daily.    ANC/PNC Hx: Mother attended ANC at a peripheral clinic, and the pregnancy was uneventful. Mother delivered by SVD at term following induced labor. She reports having had reduced fetal movements prior to delivery. The child did not cry immediately at birth, and the mother notes that the child was not resuscitated. The child later breastfed but cried after 1 hour. The child did not have a febrile illness in the immediate postnatal period but developed continuous GTC at about 6 months. She was reviewed at Katalemwa Center, where they started the child on phenobarbitone, carbamazepine, and physiotherapy. Seizures were controlled until recently when the child developed GTC and was admitted on Ward 11.  Today, No new complaints.    O/E: Child is FGC. Head circumference 46 cm (microcephaly). No pallor. No jaundice.    CNS: Neck is stiff with generalized hypotonia.    RS: Not in respiratory distress. Equal air entry bilaterally. No crepitations.    Imp: Spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy with epilepsy.    Plan:  1. Tabs carbamazepine 100 mg 12 hourly x2/52  2. Taper and stop phenobarbitone  3. Continue physiotherapy  4. Nutritional education given  5. R/V 06/06/2019

column14: First Visit (06/06/2019)    Martha was well until two years ago when she started having convulsions. The convulsions are generalized myoclonic jerks, sometimes atonic, lasting about 30 minutes and associated with loss of consciousness, but no associated upward gaze, salivation, urination, or stool incontinence. Mother reports that she gets headaches prior to the convulsions, and she goes into deep sleep after the convulsions. No history of head checks, trauma, or other chronic illnesses.     ROS: unremarkable.    Three months ago, she was in Platinum Hospital and did an EEG, which showed 2-2.5 Hz generalized spike waves/polyspike waves (286 µV) with mixed 13-13.5 Hz, 16 Hz frontally dominant, fast spike activity. Grossly slow background wakefulness for age with generalized epileptiform discharges.     No history of allergy to any drug or previous operations.    Mother lives together with her husband. They have seven children, and Martha is the last born; the other six siblings are fine. There is a family history of epilepsy in the children of her husband's brother.    Dx: Generalized childhood epilepsy    Plan:  1.	She has been on CPZ 200 mg OD x5/12.  Let's start on Carbamazepine at 100 mg OD x2/52, then consider stopping in the next visit.  2.	Tab Sodium Valproate 460 mg BD x2/12.  3.	TCA 20/06/2019.

Pregnancy & Birth: Born at term, SVD. Mother had obstructed labour. Did not cry or breastfeed immediately after birth.    Immunisation: Up to date    Growth & Development: Has poor neck control, unable to sit, started smiling at 2 months of age. Palmar grasp, mum not sure what age.    Nutrition: Exclusively breastfed for 6 months, now breastfeeds plus cow milk.    FSH: Dad is an electrical engineer, mother is a housewife.    O/E: FGC, pink, alert, not in distress. column14: Index Visit  Date of visit: 11/07/2019  Patient's weight: 6.6 kg  Age: 8 months    Ramah, 8/12-month-old girl, delivered at term by caesarean section due to prolonged labour. BWT = 3.0 kg.    C/O: Convulsions since birth, body jerks with extension of the head and eye rolling, which the mother noticed during the neonatal period. Baby did not cry immediately at birth, treated with phenobarbitone w/o improvement. Seizure activity worsened at 4/12 of age and started on carbamazepine. Seizure activity reduced on prednisolone but worsened on tapering.    EEG done on 12/04/19 showed abnormal sleep EEG with fragmented HYPSARRHYTHMIA. EEG study correlates with West syndrome.     EEG done on 25/04/19 showed focal epileptiform activity, HYPSARRHYTHMIA no longer seen.    Today, the mother reports recurrence of spasms, multiple episodes. Prednisolone 5/52.    O/E: FGC, afebrile, no pallor, no jaundice.    CNS: Fully conscious, not actively convulsing, no FND, PEARL, normal tone, posture, and reflexes.    Other systems unremarkable.    Imp: Infantile spasm = West syndrome.    Plan:  1.	Repeat EEG.  2.	Restart prednisolone at 8 mg/kg/day for 2 weeks.  R/V: 25/07/2019.    Date of visit: 28/10/2019  Patient's weight: 7.7 kg  Age: 1 year and 1/52 week    1-year-old female with West syndrome on carbamazepine, no new complaints.    O/E: FGC, afebrile, normal, no pallor, jaundice or dehydration or edema.    CNS: Conscious, PEARL, hypertonic, hyperreflexic.    RS: Not in distress, bilateral good air entry, no added sounds.    CVS: Warm peripheries, CRT <2 seconds.    P/A: Normal fullness, no organomegaly, bowel sounds normal.    Imp: 1-year-old female with West syndrome.    Plan:  1.	Continue carbamazepine.  2.	TCA on 18/11/2019.

column14: Index Visit - Date of Visit: 21/2/2019    6/52 old boy,   Referral with:     1. Jerks,   2. Nystagmoid eye movements,   3. Neck deviation, peddling and abnormal movements,   4. Inability to suck.    HPC: Baby delivered in Kitebi HC following prolonged labour plus premature rupture of membranes. Labour was augmented. BWT was 3.14 kg. Did not cry until 3/52 of age. Was able to breathe but required O2 for 2/52. To date unable to suck. Was transferred to Kawempe SCU where they spent 2/52 on O2 and NGT feeding. Discharged after 2/52 on 23/JAN/2019. Received aminophylline plus phenobarbital for neonatal seizures. No history of neonatal jaundice. Seizures in the past weeks, increasing abnormal movements with tonic neck deviation to the right, tonic eye deviation plus nystagmus to the left, unable to suck.    FSH: First born of the parents.    O/E: Sick baby, wasted, mild pallor, no jaundice, no dysmorphic features. AC = 35.3 cm.     CNS: Nystagmus to the left, poor visual behaviour, generalized hypertonia with scissoring, repeated pedaling movements, tremors and jitteriness, neck retracted, plus fascia.    R/S: NAD.    CVS: Tachycardic, normal HS1 and 2.    P/A: Liver 4 cm below the costal margin, palpable.    Imp:  1.	Previous HIE, stage 3, following prolonged labour  2.	Dyskinetic CP with dystonia  3.	? Focal epilepsy  4.	Failure to thrive  R/O: Metabolic/neurogenetic disorder    Plan:  1.	EEG: Diffuse slowing, no epileptiform activity during attacks, discharges in the left temporal area  2.	RFTs and LFTs, Ca²⁺, phosphates, serum lactate, blood sugar (RBS), ammonia and urinary  3.	Brain CT/MRI  4.	Start carbamazepine syrup, 30 mg BD  5.	Start CLONAZEPAM, 0.125 mg OD Nocte (supply 0.5 mg tabs)  6.	Nutritionist consult on therapy (FTT 200 ml/kg/day)  7.	Baclofen 2.5 mg BD  8. CNS: alert, is active, has poor neck control, hypertonia in all limbs    Other systems: Unremarkable.    Plan:  1.	Reduce syrup EPILIM to 6 ml AM and 5 ml PM ×2/52  2.	R/V on 26/11/2020  3.	Physiotherapy

This child is a known case of SCA, attending SCA clinic since September 2018 (at nine months of age), presented with a stroke last month and was admitted on ward 16 from 10/06 to 08/07/2019. Currently on physiotherapy, acetazolamide 125 mg, hydroxyurea, folic acid, paracetamol/IBUPROFEN, phenobarbitone 15 mg AM, 30 mg PM, and sodium valproate 100 mg AM and 200 mg PM. CNS: alert, stiffness in the neck, limbs occasionally spastic, right lateral gaze, right-sided hemiplegia, increased tone and DR, upgoing Babinski, unable to swallow.     R/S: not in distress, transmitted breath sounds.     CVS: warm extremities, CRT < 2 seconds, PR = 112 BPM, regular, HS1 and HS2 heard and not heard. BP = 129/88 mmHg    P/A: normal fullness, soft, no palpable organs    Imp: 1-year 6/12-month Male with SCA stroke sequel with secondary GTC seizures.    Plan:  1.	Do fundoscopy (last week, mild pale disc)  2.	Acetazolamide 125 mg BD X 2/52  3.	Tabs phenobarbitone 15 mg Nocte X  1/52  4.	Sodium valproate syrup 100 mg AM, 200 mg Nocte X 2/52  5.	Continue HU and pain management  6.	TCA 01/08/2019

column14: Index visit  Date of visit: 18/07/19    P/C: Repeated focal convulsions x4/7    HPC: Five-month-old female presented with recurrent episodes of focal jerking movements on one side of the body, mostly affecting the arm, face, and leg on one side. Can last 1-2 minutes and has multiple episodes in a day. She also has exaggerated startle response to loud sounds. The convulsion episodes are not associated with fevers.    Pregnancy: She was sick quite often during pregnancy. Received prophylactic ABX and was treated for some infection.    Birth: BWT 3.7 kg. Born by SVD. Did not cry immediately. Had neonatal sepsis and was on O₂ for eight days after birth.    Development: Has weak neck control, able to sit with support, able to smile, makes noises, able to see and recognize her mother, able to suckle.    Immunization: Up to date    Family + Social Hx: Last born of five children, they are all okay    O/E: J⁰ A⁰ C⁰ C⁰ O⁰ L⁰ D⁰. Afebrile. Head circumference 41 cm. No other dysmorphic features.     R/S: Chest has equal air entry bilaterally, bronchovesicular breath sounds  Heart sounds 1+2 heard, no chest deformities    P/A: soft, non-tender, no palpable masses    CNS: fully conscious, normal tone. While examining the child, had 3-5 rapid tongue flexion movements, resembling movements consistent with seizure    Skin: no lesions noted. Back normal.    Imp: Five-month-old who had HIE grade I as a neonate, now has benign myoclonic epilepsy of infancy? West syndrome and microcephaly    Plan:  1. Do EEG  2. Start on sodium valproate 25 mg PO BD x2/52  3. TCA 15/08/19    Date of visit: 24/02/2020  Patient's weight: 8.3 kgs  Age: 1 year    Reviewed: 1yr/F with West syndrome. Afebrile    R/S: not in distress, good air entry bilaterally, chest is clear    CVS: warm peripheries, HS1+2 normal, no added sounds    CNS: fully conscious, neck is soft, normal muscle tone and bulk.    Imp: ARI, West syndrome, LGS    Plan:  1.	Tabs Sodium Valproate 60 mg BD x 3/12  2.	Tabs Amoxicillin 125 mg 8 hourly x 5/7  3.	Continue with physiotherapy  4.	For review on 18/5/20

column14: Date of visit: 05/09/19    C/O seizures on and off X 6 years. Seizures initially involving the right side of the body with focal twitches and later getting generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Was first taken to a traditional healer from the age of 2 years with no improvement. However, 2 years ago was taken to a clinic and started on sodium valproate. The drug was of a make from India and did not cause any improvement. Change to EPILIM, UK brand, seizures changed in frequency and intensity. Currently on sodium valproate, 500 mg a.m. and 250 mg p.m. Has now X 2/ seizures per day. Has never been admitted before. Is the first child in the family of 7. Father has 2 wives. Mother is a farmer, father is a businessman. Other siblings are alive and well. The development and pregnancy history, not forthcoming, father not aware.    O/E: School age girl with bruises all over the face and scalp. A⁰ J⁰ O⁰ well hydrated, afebrile.     System exam unremarkable.    Investigations  EEG done today. AWAKE EEG shows mild diffuse slowing (moves at 3 to 6 Hz at 80 µV). Focal epileptiform discharges originating from the deep structures of the left temporal lobe.    Imp: EEG study correlates with partial epilepsy. Focal to bilateral tonic clonic seizures, poorly controlled.    Medication status on  Currently on sodium valproate, 500 mg AM and 250 mg PM    Plan  1.	Step sodium valproate to 500 mg BD x 3/12  2.	TCA 3/10/19

column14: Date of visit: 26/9/2019  Patient's age: 7/52 weeks old    NSUBUGA SHARIF, a 7/52 old male, with a history of focal convulsions since birth. Mother reports that the fits started in the evening of the same day of birth, which involves immediately both the hands for a few seconds, then after an hour becomes generalized involving both the upper and lower limbs for a few seconds. No associated eye deviation. She was treated with phenobarbitone for about five days and the convulsion stopped but again started convulsing. Then put back on phenobarbitone, but on discharge, there were no convulsions. The mother reports that the child was still having focal fits on both the arms. After 3/52, they put back on phenobarbitone.    ROS: Unremarkable    ANC/PNC Hx: She was on regular ANS, uneventful pregnancy, delivered via SVD. Baby cried immediately after birth and started breastfeeding within the first hour of birth, but administered in the evening due to convulsions.    PMH: He is immunized up to date. He is exclusively breastfeeding. No family history of seizures or chronic illness on both sides.    O/E: FGC, afebrile, not pale or jaundiced, well hydrated    R/S: Chest is clear    CVS: HS1 and 2 heard and normal, no added sounds    P/A: normal fullness, soft, non tender, liver and spleen are not palpable    CNS: fully conscious, neck is soft, anterior fontanel not bulging, normal tone and power in both upper and lower limbs    Imp: 7/52/M infant with  1.	Focal epilepsy  2.	R/O Infancy syndrome    Plan:  3.	Tabs Carbamazepine 25 mg (AM) and 50 (PM) mg BD × 2/52 (then 50 mg at night and 25 mg in the morning)  4.	TCA after 1 month  5.	Continue phenobarbitone    First visit  Date of visit: 06/08/2020    1 year old M infant on treatment for focal epilepsy plus delayed milestones on carbamazepine - well controlled. They have no complaints. Is able to sit without support, plays well, active.    O/E: FGC, asleep, JACCOLD ⁰     SYS: NAD    CNS: Asleep, reduced tone    Impression: Focal epilepsy    Plan:  1.	Continued Tabs Carbamazepine 100 mg (AM) 50 mg (PM) × 2/12  2.	TCA 10/09/2020

column14: Date of visit: 3/10/2019  Patient's weight: 10.1 kg  Age: 1-year 4/12 months old    Referral from GULU LACOR Hospital with abnormal jerks.    HPC: Baby born via SVD, BWT 2.8 kg at 38/40. Developed vomiting in the first week. A diagnosis of pyloric stenosis was made. Operated in LACOR. The laparotomy was repeated and she developed multiple wound infections and delayed wound healing. During this time, also had multiple seizures, GTC seizures. This was controlled well until approximately 4/12. Initially stopped but recurred in the past 3/12. Now she mostly gets jerks in sleep or on awakening. Multiple episodes lasting less than 1 minute. Also uses the left side less than the right. Also impaired vision. Development has been delayed. At 1 year and 4 months, is only able to sit and bottom shuffle. No speech.    FSH: No family history known    O/E: FGC, had appendectomy, A⁰, J⁰, no dysmorphic features, no neurocutaneous lesions.     CNS: mild left VII palsy, RUL power 4/5, RLL power 4/5.     Other systems: Normal    Impression:   1. ? Perinatal/prenatal stroke with mild left sided weakness   2. Epilepsy symptomatic   3. Developmental delay (global)   4. Previous pyloric stenosis    Plan:  1.	EEG  2.	Brain imaging  3.	Review with results    Main risk factors: Perinatal/prenatal stroke

At 1 month old, the child had convulsions, which were generalized not associated with loss of consciousness. The last convulsion was yesterday, lasting >5 minutes. column14: Date of visit: 12/12/2019  Patient's weight: 29.9 kg  Age: 3 years 9/12 months old     P/C: Sudden falls since age of 2 ½ years.   Seizures in the right upper limb × 2/12. Child had been growing until about two and a half years when she suddenly began falling. Child would fall over 10 times a day. Child was started on carbamazepine ¼ tab at a clinic and later escalated to ¾ tab, which she took for about two months and was discontinued by the parents. The child has had no improvement. She has been off medication for over 10 months. Two months ago, the child developed myoclonic seizures in the right upper limb with no specific pre-ictal trigger or aura. Lasts about three to five minutes with post-ictal drowsiness and GBW. Child has loss of consciousness during this seizure period. She gets up to three episodes a week. However, the falls still persist daily.    ANC/PNC Hx: Mother reports pregnancy (third pregnancy) was uneventful. She had normal labor and delivery. Child cried immediately. Weighed 3.4 kg.  Growth and Developmental History: Growth and development was normal. Child achieved all milestones on time.    FSHx: Third born of four children. There is positive family history of epilepsy on the paternal side.    O/E: Active child, good nutritional status, weight 29.9 kg, no pallor, no jaundice, no dysmorphic features. Child has scars on the face and head following previous falls.     CNS: Alert    RS and PA: Normal Findings    Impression: Myoclonic and absent seizures    Investigations: EEG done on 14/01/2019 showed generalized bilaterally symmetrical epileptiform discharges (spikes and waves at 3-4 Hz)  Conclusion: Generalized idiopathic epilepsy (absence)    Plan  1. Tab Sodium Valproate 250 mg 12 hourly × 1/12  2. Review on 06/01/2020

column14: Index Visit  Date of Visit: 11/01/2018    History:    Chief Complaint: Convulsions for 3 months with delayed milestones      History of Present Illness:   The child has been having focal seizures for 3 months, limited to the upper limbs, lasting 2min seizures are tonic-clonic and are not associated with loss of consciousness, drooling, or incontinence. The mother reports seizures occur once every other week and also gets stiffness.   The index episode of seizures was on the 3rd day of life, the child had been born by SVD, Bwt- 2.5kg, and discharged with no issues.  On day 3, the child developed irritability, refused to breastfeed, and later developed generalized tonic convulsions for 2days. She was started on antibiotics with some improvement. The child was delayed to breastfeed but restarted after a 1 week.  Has delayed milestones and cannot sit unsupported as yet.  Mother is seronegative.     Family and Social History (FSH):  4th born in a family of 4 children, and other 3 kids are well. No FHx of epilepsy, no history of seizures in the family.    On Examination:  General: FGC, afebrile, no jaundice, anaemia, dehydration, cyanosis, or clubbing.    Central Nervous System (CNS): irritable, microcephaly, no facial palsies. Anterior fontalle is closed, normal tone of the limbs.    Other Systemic Examination: Normal findings.    Investigations:  EEG Findings:   1.	 Epileptic encephalopathy  2.	Generalized epilepsy  3.	Atonic myoclonic seizures    Impression:  Focal seizures r/o Epilepsy  Plan:  1.	Do EEG  2.	Syrup sodium valproate 40mg (AM) 40mg (PM) × 1/12  3.	Counselled mother    Date of Visit: 13/5/2018  Weight: 8.5kg    1year and 6 months / female with global development delay and focal seizures. Has been stable, has no seizures has FOCS involving knocking of knuckles together.     On Examination:  General: FGC, afebrile, no jaundice, anaemia, dehydration, cyanosis, or clubbing.    Central Nervous System (CNS): alert, generalized hypertonic with brisk reflexes.    Other Systemic Examination: Normal findings.    Impression: - Focal seizures with Global   Development Delay / C.P    Plan:- 1) Continue with Sodium Valproate              2) link to C.P clinic              3) R/v on 26/7/2018

column14: Date of visit: 26/02/18  Age: 1 year old    1year old/M, syndromic baby with repaired left lip/palate and microcephaly referred to neuro clinic. Previously admitted to PICU with H/O fever, DIB and convulsions. Currently the main complaint is frequent repetitive convulsions since birth. His generalized seizures are in nature, eye rolling, urinary incontinence. Seizures occur twice a day. Some improvement on treatment. Calvin was born by SVD, BWT 3.6 kg, cried immediately after delivery but was difficult to initiate breastfeeding due to left lip/palate. The child feeds cow's milk never breastfed. Baby normal maturation/stool. Baby was never immunized due to illness. Sero status negative. Mother concerns about the delay of sitting, growth and development. Not growing well, not able to sit at 9/12, not able to see out, not reacting with light.     FSHx: Sixth baby in the family. Has two from the same father. Second last is also deaf. N/S drops TDS × 1/52  5.	EEG TCA 12/03/2018

column57: Date of visit: 08/07/19  Patient's weight: 4.4 kg    2-and-a-half-year-old/ M, syndromic infant, poorly controlled epilepsy on Sodium Valproate 10 mg per kg for 6/12. CNS alert, neck soft, hypertonia in all limbs, decreased muscle bulk.    Imp: Syndromic infant with   1.	Poorly controlled epilepsy  2.	Aspiration Pneumonia   Plan:  3. column14: Index Visit  Date of visit: 15/03/2018  Patient's Weight: 8.5 kg    7 months old infant who presents with abnormal movements since the age of about 3½ months. Great grandmother reports that she would have these abnormal movements 3-4 times a day and they would come mostly when she is about to go to sleep and each would last approximately 1 minute. There was no rolling of the eyes or frothing of saliva. There is no urine or fecal incontinence. Great grandmother also reports that there is Hx of dysuria, foul smelling, but has not done anything with regard to that. There is no associated blowing of the mucous membranes when having the convulsions.  The child has been attending cerebral palsy clinic for the past 1 month and the grandmother has acknowledged great improvement with physiotherapy. Currently can sit without support at 7 months.  First child to a teenage mother (17 years) who went back to school (currently in S6) and has been living with her grandmother (patient's great grandmother) since she delivered. She delivered in hospital 2 weeks before EDD. She cannot remember circumstances surrounding the delivery because she lost consciousness and had an episiotomy.  BWT: 2 kg  The child was breastfed until 5½ months before being weaned off formula feeds. Baby is still breastfeeding. Immunization as per schedule. Awaiting measles at 9 months.    O/E: FGC, afebrile, no pallor, no cyanosis, no jaundice, no dysmorphic features. Normotensive anterior fontanel. Has hyperreflexia more pronounced in the lower limb. No hyper/hypopigmented lesions. Clonus negative    RS: Not in distress, good equal air entry with transmitted sounds and bronchovesicular breath sounds    CVS: HS1 and 2 heard and normal, pulse rate is regular    P/A: Soft, no palpable organs or masses  Impression: Infantile myoclonus spasms    Plan:  1.	EEG  2.	Tabs Sodium Valproate 100 mg OD × 2/52  3.	Saline nasal drops  4.	TCA in 2/52 weeks. column14: Date of Visit: 23/03/18  Patient's Weight: 18.8 kg    5 y/o male, known ISS on HAART (ABC/3TC 60/30 mg BD), Dolutegravir 25 mg OD, INH prophylaxis, Clotrimoxazole prophylaxis and Pyridoxine. Comes with a history of generalized tonic convulsions with rapid eye movements and abnormal grunting sounds. Has had three episodes in the past two months. The first episode occurred in February. Then this March he has had three episodes. All these convulsions occurred in the night when he is asleep. Usually starts by the episode of vomiting followed by convulsions. Each convulsion lasts five to ten minutes with associated urine incontinence. Thereafter the child normalizes and sleeps for about four to five hours. Mother is unable to tell whether there is loss of consciousness after the episodes. Convulsions are not associated with fevers or any febrile illness. They are of spontaneous onset. ROS is unremarkable. There is no history of head trauma prior to these convulsions. However, the mother reports that in the past, the child had an episode of meningitis for which he was treated at two weeks of age. Thereafter he's been fine. Child is also HIV seropositive on treatment. He also attends the chest clinic for allergies, but has since improved. PSHx: No H/O perinatal/PNC Hx. Baby was delivered premature at about 30 weeks. Birth weight was 2.3 kg. Child was well at birth, cried immediately, was admitted at birth and discharged to home when stable. Immunization completed. Schedule nutrition currently on adult diet. Growth and development: achieved all milestones on time.    O/E: Very hyperactive boy, moving all over the place. Plays, utters, attention but good nutritional status, J⁰ A⁰ D⁰ O⁰    CNS: alert, GCS: 15/15, PEARL, Neck soft, Normal muscle bulk, Normal tone, No pathological neurological deficits, Normal reflexes    R/S: unremarkable    CVS: unremarkable    P/A: unremarkable    EEG: study correlates with electrical status epilepticus with continuous spikes and waves during sleep    Impression: Generalized tonic epilepsy, ? ADHD    Plan:  1.	Tabs Carbamazepine 10 mg/kg (100 mg BD) × 1/52  2.	R/V 29/03/18

column14: Date of Visit: 25/01/2018  Patient's Weight: 12 Kg    Seen a 4-year-old girl, brought in by her guardian, she is the 2nd twin, and the other twin (also a girl) is fine at home and healthy. Both parents passed away early last year, the father died first then the mother died later (unknown cause to the guardian).  Reported history of a febrile illness in sept 2017, followed by loss of consciousness for 4days later developed convulsions which were initially mild seizures but now are progressing to become generalized tonic-clonic. Initially, it involved only the right hand and mouth.  During the course of their illness she was admitted to Mengo Hospital and treated for malaria, and pneumonia not remembering the medication the child was on. NO LP was done.  Initially was able to talk and make a full sentence but now only 2words.    FSH:4th born in a family of 4 children, and the other 3 kids are well.   No FHx of epilepsy, no history of seizures in the family.    On Examination:  General: FGC, afebrile, no jaundice, anaemia, dehydration, cyanosis, or clubbing.    CNS: can talk 2 words only, abnormal gait (staggering limping), Alert, neck is soft, noted abnormal movement-clonic.  Tone is normal, and power- normal on both lower limbs left upper limb but weak (3/5) on the Rt upper limb. She can't hold a pen using her right upper limb.    Other Systemic Examination: Normal findings.    Investigations:  CT scan showing the Left parietal occipital has some brain atrophy    Impression:  1)	Epilepsy  2)	Left sided stroke with cerebellar lesions.    Plan:  1.	Do EEG  2.	Tab carbamazepine 100mg at Am and 50mg at Pm.  3.	Physiotherapy  4.	TCA: 2weeks 8/2/2018

column14: Date of Visit: 05/09/2019  Patient's Weight: 8.0 kg    Child presents with h/o seizures on & off since the of 1/12 month. The child is now 11/12 months old. The seizures involve sudden flexion of the head with extension of arms moving forward. The child was a full-term normal delivery with no complications during delivery. However, during pregnancy at 32 weeks, had 2 episodes of unspecified skin rash, for which she received undocumented medication with improvement. The child was started on prednisolone and Sodium Valproate for 2/52 in December 2018 and the seizure frequency reduced. However, since 2/12, the child has been off medication and the frequency has increased to greater than 20 times a day. The child is currently on Sodium Valproate 160 mg. The third child in the family of 2; the second-born died in vitro at 5 months. The mother sells second-hand clothes, and the father sells scrap in IGANGA town council.    O/E: Irritable child, afebrile, moderate pallor, no jaundice, no edema, no oral sores, no skin rash. Afebrile to touch    R/V: breath sounds normal, no added sounds    CNS: Conscious, neck soft, muscle bulk normal, reduced tone and power in all limbs, deep tendon reflexes not done.    EEG done on 05/09/2019, abnormal sleep EEG showing fragmented hips, arrhythmia, which correlates with West syndrome.    Impression:  1. West syndrome    Plan  1. Start on Prednisolone 4 mg per kg × 2/52, then taper for 2 mg per kg to complete 8 weeks  2. Slowly taper Sodium Valproate and stop (Tabs Sodium Valproate 120 mg BD)  3. TCA 19/09/2019    Date of visit: 17/10/2019    1-year-old female with West syndrome. Reported to be free from convulsions since the start of treatment, although reported history of thrusts, laughing, and rolling eyes up. She has delayed milestones.    O/E: FGC, afebrile, apathy, no cyanosis, no pallor, no jaundice, no dehydration, no edema, temperature 36.4°C    CNS: Conscious    Physical Exam: A⁰, J⁰, O⁰, hypotonia, normal reflexes    R/S: Not in distress, oxygen 98%, bilateral good air entry. The child was on O2 before.     CVS: warm peripheries, CRT less than 2, S1 and S2 heard.    Impression:    1.	Infantile spasms, West syndrome  Plan  1.	Continue Sodium Valproate 120 mg PO BD X 1/12  2.	Do physiotherapy  3.	Repeat EEG  4.	TCA on 18/11/19
